course.name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.content: Computer Science is a difficult topic to lecture. Blaer truly embodies that. His teaching is definitely difficult to keep up with because its just so boring. He's monotone, but not monotone in a quiet kinda way--monotone in a LOUD kinda way. He does record his lectures and give late days for assignments which are a huge plus and it seems like he understands that people go through things/make mistakes.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Weekly ZyBooks assignments--superrrr helpful and a great investment for the class. Not a TON of work and answers are visible for help.

Weekly Codio/Gradescope assignments which are not too difficult as well.

reviews.content: Cannon is great and is happy to answer endless, repetitive questions. But actually, he is a very patient teacher and a really good at explaining and genuinely feels like he cares about preparing the next generation of computer scientists!!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10% Zybook, 40% HW, 10% Midterm 1, 10% midterm 2, 30% Final

reviews.content: Had absolutely no prior cs experience, but cannon made the class very doable/enjoyable. lecture pace is super slow and are not too necessary to attend imo(especially near the end), but he'll occasionally drop hints for exam context. definitely go to OH's / form groups to code with for assignments and do the practice exams in their entirity! Midterms were super similar to the practice exams, the final was a bit harder / had a different format. Blair and Cannon have near-identical class structures, but Cannon teaches in the spring and seems to be slightly harder.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: dedicate time to do the odd-even game and poker assignment, especially

reviews.content: the goat, makes CS easy to understand both conceptually and syntax-wise. If you have to take a CS course at columbia i'd say taking one with him is a pretty safe bet.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 40% assignment projects, 10% zybook, 10% both midterms, & 30% final. If you put in the effort and do all the work it isn't terribly difficult to do well in the course.

reviews.content: Everyone told me such great things about Professor Blaer, and honestly he sets the bar really low for doing well in the class. He's super engaging in class and him + the TAs always care about your work and will respond to any emails / Ed Discussions. Content is a little difficult if you haven't taken a Java course before, but he does explain things if you haven't.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Work was so easy and grading was incredibly fair. Spent about 2 hours max per week on this class and maybe 3-4 hours studying for the midterms/finals just to review content.

reviews.content:
Disclaimer is that I have never touched cs before. Ever. So this course was definitely a challenge. Blaer is friendly, straightforward, hilarious in lectures at times, but he definitely does sort of assume a foundational type of knowledge on how code works. I didn't feel like we had time to absorb the foundations before starting on subtopics. After I got the basic principles in my head though, it went much better, and I did well starting from the midterms. I never showed up to the lectures in person, personally found it much more helpful to rewatch the recordings at 2x speed, coding along, pausing and replaying parts at my own pace. Lecture content feels a little disjointed at first, not always clear how everything connects, so you do need to read and do! the! ZyBooks! Not gonna lie though, this course would've taken me a lot longer if it weren't for me basically using GPT4 as an on demand tutor/TA, helping explain to me textbook and lecture content, as well as providing more practice questions. 

Overall still a good course. Feel very meh about the subject though, just wanted to try.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Assignments were perfectly doable on my own, with minor clarification from TAs, as long as I had a good grasp of the lecture and textbook content. Grading is fine. Blaer's very clear about when regrade requests are due, just get them in before then and they'll handle it. Lowest even and lowest odd numbered HW assignment grade is also dropped (very appreciated, given that I couldn't turn 2 assignments in even by the late deadline). Finals was tough but with a lot of studying it also went fine.

reviews.content:
Okay, so disclaimer, I never did Java before this class, but I do have programming experience in Python, which made it easier for me to grasp Java concepts and figure out coding logic.

 For starters, I do not really like Blaer's teaching style, its kinda all over the place and there arent any slides or anything. Its more like he codes and talks. Honestly, I did not find it helpful to go to lecture because of this. I found it a better use of my time to just learn Java on my own. 

The homeworks do progressively get harder and more time consuming, so my advice is to start early and go to TA OH. Some TAs are better than others imo cuz some of them would not even know what the assignment is about while others were more prepared to answer questions, so find out which TAs work better for you. Also, check EDStem while doing HW, because often the HW instructions are not very specific and there will be new requirements that are not mentioned in the HW instructions that you only find out about because someone else asked about it on ED Stem.

I do like that Blaer tells you what topics are going to be on the exam before hand so that you know what to really drill down for the exam. I only went to Blaer's OH one time, and he was lowkey condescending. I asked my question in a respectful manner so I think the rudeness was uncalled for.  If many people are saying hes unapproachable then I doubt this was just a one time thing. 

Grading for this class is chill though, its curved well. I ended up with an A w a raw of 92. Class average was like a 70 for the final and midterm.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.content:
As someone with little experience in Java, this class was definitely difficult. I would only take this course if you are seriously interested in majoring/minoring in CS - it is not just an elective you can push off to the side. I took COMS1004 to see if I wanted to major in CS and realized it wasn't for me, so the last couple of months were a pain to get through because the homework gets harder and harder. Honesty, everything after the midterm dramatically increased in difficulty. I also found the homework to be inordinately difficult compared to the exams. Expect to spend 5-10 hours on each homework, probably more on the Poker assignment. 

Blaer is a very charismatic and enjoyable lecturer. However, if you are someone who doesn't know what is going on, it's easy to get confused because he incorporates jargon that we learned in class into his explanations. If you don't understand a previous concept, MAKE SURE you figure it out asap.

As someone who got an A and was incredibly confused half of the semester, my best advice is to 1) Start HW early and go to office hours for help. There are lots of TAs so I'd suggest going to different ones and figuring out which TAs you like; 2) Actually read the Zybooks and make sure you know how to do all of the problems. For greater understanding, do the challenge problems; 3) Go to the review sessions and study everything he says for the midterm/final. I found YouTube and previous lectures/HWs to be helpful. Final and midterm are similarly structured, and if you're confused start with memorizing the syntax of the algorithms he covers (binary search, linear search, max/min, selection/insertion sort).

I took ESP and that was a super chill, surface-level introduction to CS concepts.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 40% Homework, 10% Zybooks participation (only need to do 80% to get full credit), 20% Midterm, 30% Final. The raw average for my semester was an 82, and he curves the average to a low B+ and the median to an A-, so it is pretty fair.

reviews.content: Great Professor who understands Java inside and out. Even if you come with knowledge of programming already (which I did with python) you will still learn a lot and maybe fall in love with java. If you didn't you will be fine and you will learn a lot and maybe fall in love with programming. The most important thing I realized is to code along with Prof Blaer during his lectures. Just open a personal Codio Project and type with him as he codes on his computer. Coding > taking notes and you will do well on the exam. When it comes to exams Prof Blaer does half the work for you already. He lists out all that you need to know in a txt file. All you have to do is just reimplement (from your understanding/memory) what's on the list two days before the exam. Allow one day of sleep to commit to memory and you will get 90+ on exams. It worked for me and it may work for you but everyone has their own study methods! Have fun!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Extremely fair grading. Hours depend on how comfortable you are with the material.

reviews.content:
Overall positive experience. Professor Blaer is a very kind person. He is the most understanding professor of all the professors I have taken class with. He truly tries his best to adjust the release date and homework deadline to make our lives easier because he understands we have a lot of work to do.
He and the TAs are also very supportive, super quick in responding questions on ed.

I have to however agree with other comments that I don't love his teaching style. He is not bad at explaining concepts, but there are no slides or complementary notes for most coding lectures and therefore the learning process feels unstructured. The strategy is to make your own notes with the recordings after class, because it's hard to make a structured notes in class when you don't know where he's going. I however did not realize this early on and did not make my own notes. So although I ended up an A I feel like I did not have a clear picture of what I have learned.
It's a bit ironic because the logistics stuff in this class are pretty structured and organized in my opinion.

I personally did not encounter any difficulties in seeking support, so I disagree with other comments saying he is unapproachable.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
10 homework assignments (40%), weekly Zybook exercises (10%), a midterm exam (20%), and a final exam (30%)
Zybook is basically reading assignments with coding exercises.

Average, maybe a bit heavier workload if you have no coding experience.

Grading is fair. The written responses for both homework and exams, however, are strict in a way that you have to answer exactly what they are expecting. I got points deducted because the response not 100% the same with the rubric, although I already show clear understanding to the question.

reviews.content: I had previously taken APCSA before so I didn't find this class to be particularly challenging. However, I think it would be for someone who has no coding experience as it can be quite fast. Classes tend to consist of Professor Blaer coding something and talking through his process. Attendance is optional and all classes can be attended on zoom, in-person, or watched at a later time (lectures are recorded). Professor Blaer is very funny and relaxed.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: There are 10 homework assignments and additional practice problems and readings (about 10 total). Some of the homeworks take longer than others (anywhere from 20 min to 6 hours) and overall I would say the workload is fair. Practice problems and readings often took me about an hour. The TAs grading can be a little harsh and inconsistent because there are about 20 TAs.

reviews.content: Dr Paul Blaer is a terrible professor. His lecture isn't worth going to because he talks about himself half of the time. He frequently changes his schedule to compensate for his poor lifestyle decisions and expects students to adjust to it. He's existed at Columbia as a professor because he clueless with fundamentals such as JSON which are heavily used in the profession and would never last in corporate. His TAs take off points for no reason then they make you fill out a "regrade request form" to fix their grading error and never entertain it. Its amazing that a university such as Columbia employs him when they have so many better options. Dr Blaer is unable to uphold any standards and grades out of his own complacency. Such a waste of time & money.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: He fails to make assignments live on time. I've had points deduced from several correct answers and the TAs act like its your problem when you confront them about it.

reviews.content: Professor Blaer is an amazing lecturer and does a good job of keeping the class interesting. He's generally very organized when it comes to the material he's covering and was not unfair about grading or what should be expected for each assignment. His office hours are very brief though and he can come off as unfriendly during them, so I would only recommend attending them if you really need help that only he can provide (otherwise his TA's should be enough). If you have an ounce of coding background this class is fairly light; just pay attention to the lectures and you'll be fine. If you're completely new, I would recommend watching Java videos to supplement the lecture/textbook material since I've heard it can be quite confusing on its own.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: There were some coding assignments that weren't terribly hard and some written assignments that were a bit strict with how they were graded. I would 100% say though that if you study well enough and pay attention none of the assignments or exams are too difficult.

reviews.content:
Taking Intro Java with Adam Cannon has been a great experience. He makes his lectures engaging, wants to connect with his students and genuinely cares about everyone in the class. You learn the basics of Java and get a good grasp of whether pursuing a CS Major/Minor might be of interest.

That being said, for someone who has never programmed before the class can be challenging, especially the second half of it. However going to OH helps and there is generally speaking a good curve.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Quite high, especially if you've never programmed before. Weekly Readings, Homework Assignments. 2 Midterms and 1 Final

reviews.content: I had some background in Java so this class wasn't too difficult for me but it was to others. Blaer is an overall nice professor, however beware that there is not much "teaching" in class, more-so practice of textbook concepts.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Assignments were not overly difficult and were graded fairly. Maybe spent 1 hour most times on assignments, up to 2-3 hours on the more difficult ones, but again did have some experience in Java.

reviews.content: Adam Cannon is a great professor! He really cares about his students. I loved this class but if you are completely new to CS it may be somewhat difficult, because CS is just a hard subject! But it's worth it! I think the class prepared me well for Data Structures. If you don't plan to major in CS then Computing in Context might be a better option for you (same professor!)

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Grading and exams were very fair.

reviews.content: Was absolutely terrified going in given my little experience in the subject but Professor Blaer explained the content very well, he’s a super kind professor and also pretty funny. First few days is just teaching the basic definitions and ideas but then we went straight into coding, the coding in class would relate to our homework as well. Was absolutely horrified at my midterm grade but the final really saved my butt, there’s also an overall curve on your grade at the end of the semester so don’t be scared if you failed a HW or the midterm. Content mostly covered the basics of Java like operators, arrays, importing Java resources, command line arguments, Boolean, recursion, etc.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: If I remember correctly, there were 10 assignments, half were coding and the others were written (theory and such). There is one midterm worth 20%, HW is worth 50% and final is 30%, I did spend a lot of time on the HW probably 10-12 hours on the worst one but it was doable. Professor Blaer’s grading is fair, TA hours are SUPER HELPFUL, got a B+ in this class and I’m content with that :).

reviews.content:
I'd like to start off this review by saying that I already knew how to code in JavaScript, so things like if statements, while loops, etc. was just a review. When it came to things that were knew to me, though, it took a long time to learn them and grasp a basic understanding of each concept. I can't even begin to imagine what this course would have been like for someone who knew absolutely no code. (If you have time, I would recommend watching intro to Java videos on YouTube to get preliminary exposure to the content!) The assignments were hard, I'm not gonna lie. Especially the programming ones. For the biggest assignments I probably spent close to 15 hours/week on them, and still wasn't able to get a perfect score. When it comes to TA's, you just have to find the good ones. Some of them simply don't show up or don't know what they are doing, and some of them are better then Blaer tbh. Also, ALWAYS REQUEST REGRADES!!! I can't even count the amount of times TA's messed up my grade, even on the Midterm. When in doubt, just send a regrade request. 

Blaer is a fun prof. He tells fun stories and will go over concepts again for better understanding. Sometimes he glosses over things that are actually important though, so I would recommend re-watching parts of lectures closer to the exams to make you studied everything.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 assignments (5 theoretical/written, 5 programming), and the lowest score from each category is dropped. 1 midterm and 1 final. HWs are 50% of the grade, though, so focus on those. He also curves the class at the end, so it makes up for the harsh grading. The programming assignments take a long time, so start them early and go to TA's when you need help.

reviews.content: Professor Blaer is super funny and he is active on Reddit, commented on my post about him which caught me as a surprise. His class is never boring and he always makes time to answer any questions any students have. He does Zoom meetings for all his lectures and uploads them on Canvas. As a student with 0 prior experience in programming, his lectures are easy enough to follow and he explains the concepts very thoroughly. I would like to take Data Structures in Java class with him as well but unfortunately, he has taken sabbaticals. I would highly recommend taking his classes if you can.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 homeworks (5 written and 5 coding) with lowest odd numbered and even numbered homework dropped. HW - 50%, Midterm - 20% and Final - 30%. He had review sessions before both exams where he basically tells us what will be on the exam but the actual exams had a little twists here and there. Generously curved up the final grade which I got B from C grade.

reviews.content: Overall, I liked this class. I'm writing this after taking Data Structures. Honestly, I sort of wish I took Blaer for 1004 just because I felt like I didn't really understand some of the harder concepts (abstraction, encapsulation, recursion, etc) when Blaer brought them up in DS. Cannon's lecture style wasn't for me personally. It was mostly just going through code on Codio and to me felt a bit disorganized. The intro concepts - primitives, loops, etc - were explained well and thoroughly in my opinion, but some of the harder stuff not so much.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: I usually spent an 1-2 hrs a week on programming assignments. More on hw 8 iirc. Start early and use office hours - find the TAs that help you most and you'll be good. Grading was very reasonable.

reviews.content: Professor Cannon is a phenomenal professor. He is incredibly approachable, kind, and funny. All of Professor Cannon's lectures were extremely engaging, and he clearly explains concepts (My fellow classmates, remember when he repeatedly emphasizes that instance variables are initialized in the constructor of a class). Despite having prior Computer Science experience, I learned so much about Java in this course. Professor Cannon really tries to help his students learn and complete the assignments. For example, for Assignment #8, which was the Crazy Eights game and the hardest assignment in the course, Professor Cannon made a review video and session to help us with the assignment. He also gave every student in my section a 48-hour extension on that assignment. Professor Cannon is also always open to feedback from students. During the class before the second Midterm, he initially planned to help us with the Deck class of the Crazy Eights game, but after listening to students about their worries regarding the Midterm, he decided to answer students' questions instead. I, as well as my classmates, will admit that Professor Cannon gives challenging assignments. However, Professor Cannon and the TAs, especially Griffin Newbold (he TAs for Cannon in Computing in Content and for his Intro Java course), enjoy helping students and answering their questions both on Ed Discussion and during office hours. I worked very hard on the assignments regardless of their difficulty, and as a result, I learned a lot about Java from Professor Cannon's challenging assignments. The challenge of his course allows students to learn a lot and be amazing programmers. Despite challenging his students, Professor Cannon is never demanding, unkind, or condescending. He cares much more about his students learning and becoming excellent programmers than about their grades. The Final Exam had a 67.8% average, but since the class average grade at the end of the semester was less than the high B cutoff, Professor Cannon curved his students' grades to a high B. Don't worry! Professor Cannon does not want his students to fail, and he never curves down; instead, as I said, he is concerned about his students learning, not about their grades. After each of our Midterms, he even told his students in lecture that if they do not get good grades in tests, they are not bad people :)

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Professor Cannon's grade breakdown:
11 programming assignments (lowest gets dropped, counts for 50% in total)
Two Midterm Exams (counts for 10% each)
One Final Exam (counts for 30%)

Some of the programming assignments were challenging to understand and debug, so make sure to go to office hours and ask for help on Ed Discussion. Both Midterms consisted of 30 multiple choice questions. If you are good at Computer Science, work hard in the class, and are not a bad test taker, you will probably pass the Midterms or even do great on them. The averages for Midterms were late 70% to early 80%. The Final Exam had multiple choice questions, short answer questions (they only require you to write a word or a line of code), and coding questions. Professor Cannon made the Final Exam more challenging than the Midterms (I am assuming from my personal experience that most of the challenge was in the coding portion). The class average for the Final Exam was 67.8%, but Professor Cannon curved to a high B. Make sure you study hard for the Final Exam and try your best on it to really benefit from the curve.

Professor Cannon's grading is only somewhat fair. I think the TAs applied the style guide quite harshly when grading the programming assignments, to the point that the grading seemed untransparent to me. There were guidelines students can easily apply from the style guide with minimal or no mistakes; however, the TAs sometimes gave students a grade deduction for something that pertains to style but was not fully explained by them and Professor Cannon. For example, I once received a style guide violation for writing excessive comments, but Professor Cannon and the TAs did not fully explain to me in advance how to write good comments. They did tell us numerous times to write comments in our code.

On average, I spent four to thirty hours per week on assignments for this course. The amount of time I spent on the assignments varied based on their difficulty. I found Homeworks 8 and 9 to be incredibly challenging, so I spent immense time on them (around thirty hours). On the other hand, a few assignments were simple and easier, so I did not have to spend as much time on them. I spent a few hours studying for each Midterm Exam, but I almost always joined the weekly review sessions. To clarify, I mean, apart from the weekly review sessions, I spent a few hours watching other recorded review sessions, asking questions on Ed Discussion and in TAs' office hours, and reviewing my notes and code from class. My scores on Midterms 1 and 2 were 26/30 and 27/30, respectively. On the first Midterm, which was online and all multiple-choice, I accidentally clicked the wrong answer choice, so I would say I really earned 27/30. I studied around fourteen hours for the Final Exam, and this also includes the Final Exam review session a few TAs hosted. My grade on the Final Exam was 81%, which is greater than the class average and two points less than the upper quartile, but the Final Exam was harder than the Midterms.

My final grade in the class was 90.6% or an A!

reviews.content: He gives a lot of time to finish your assignments. He gave us 9 grace days and an additional 48 hours on one of the harder assignments. TA's were great and helpful. TONS of resources given to you to pass the class. Very hard to fail this class unless you turn in close to zero homework and do bad on exams.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 11 homeworks 2 midterms and 1 final. Homework 50%, midterms 10% each, and 30% for the final. Workload is manageable as long as you know how to manage your time. Do not fall behind as it is very hard to catch up even if you have programming experience. Overall, not too bad of a class if you are new or experienced in programming.

reviews.content: As someone who got a 5 on the AP CS A exam in high school, was expecting to sort of breeze through the class, and I did... sort of. He is definitely a push-over and people pleaser, to the point where it gets a little annoying and interferes with actually learning. His lectures somehow move too fast, too slow, and manage to cover nothing of actual use in regards to exams or homeworks. The homeworks were either ridiculously easy or difficult, and, while not completely his fault, it was nearly impossible to get quality help on assignments from TAs. If you don't need to take the class or can take it with a different professor, avoid Cannon.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: While the curve hasn't been released yet, the grading is surprisingly rigid for a teacher who cares so much about being liked by his students. Homeworks are worth an inordinate amount of the grade, while both midterms are pretty inconsequential. Generally though, a very low time commitment class.

reviews.content: This is not an introductory class at all. This man expects you to already know most things. He doesn't go over most concepts as they are "too trivial" and you will end up very lost on the homework assignments. It is possible to get very high grades in this class- I was completely new to programming and wasn't even intending to be a CS major so I had a VERY hard time adjusting to his lecture style and the concepts. But I had to study a disgusting amount of time just to understand the lectures. The midterm is mostly handwriting code and even though he "tells you every question on the exam," that review session is like two days before the exam and probably won't help much if you're a normal student with problem sets and other exams to study for. He also teaches new concepts that are on the exam literally the last lecture before the exam date, so nothing even marinates in time for you to apply what you learned on the exam. If you don't have prior experience in CS, you should prolly take it with a diff professor because you won't actually LEARN anything, it'll just be you trying to survive the assignments and exams.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Grading is very fair and probably the most lenient out of all the other professors.

reviews.content:
I highly recommend this class with Blaer. If you have the chance to take Java 1004 with him, do it. 

He is a very entertaining lecturer who shares fun stories while still effectively teaching all the material. 

I came in with no CS experience, and there was a bit of a learning curve, but this class made me want to be a CS major. I loved it so much. It was a good amount of work, especially the first semester, to just understand the syntax of everything. It was a lot like learning a new language. But once I got the hang of things it was fine. 

He does the lectures in person, but also streams them on zoom so you can watch online if you’d like. They’re also all recorded and posted to courseworks, so you can watch whenever you want and rewatch for review. That is super helpful. 

Only bad thing about this class is that even though there are a crazy amount of TA’s, it’s hard to have significant one on one time with a TA in office hours because they’re so crowded. You really have to come in with one specific question rather than just a general statement of confusion. It’s just a huge class and everyone wants help at office hours, so it’s hard to get much attention. 

Also we got our semester grade super late: January 18. That sucked. 

I also took Java Labs, which I would recommend for the grade boost and for having more time learning the material. 

tldr; great class! awesome professor who is both effective and entertaining. had no experience and made me want to be a cs major

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Workload was okay. Lots of work to understand in the beginning but got better. 10 homework assignments, and two were dropped.

reviews.content:
Disclaimer: After this class I became a computer science major. 

I feel this class was an effective and comprehensive introduction to programming. Blaer is an entertaining and passionate lecturer. I will say that Blaer will lie to you about how quickly you will get grades back. I will say that it is likely not the best introductory class for you if you are not planning to major or minor. 

This class can be intimidating. It is a massive lecture class. My section had ~400 students and the class overall had ~600. Most students also seem to have some programming experience. I came in with no programming experience and did find it intimidating. The difficulty of the homework assignments does increase rapidly. 

However, there is a fair grading breakdown and support available. 

I took this class in conjunction with Emerging Scholars Program and Java Labs. I greatly enjoyed both and found them to be low commitment but worthwhile. Would recommend Java Labs for anyone with no prior experience. ESP was a very interesting high-level overview of Computer Science fields.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Intense but manageable.
Ten homework assignments, 5 programming, 5 written assignments distributed over the course of the semester. 150 late hours given, lowest homework grade dropped. One midterm and one final. Both curved, though the method of curving is opaque.

reviews.content: The course content mainly pertained to programming in Java rather than foundational concepts in computer science. While we did occasionally touch on topics like computer memory, these were very briefly presented in relation to a programming concept rather than as distinct topics to be familiar with. Professor Blaer is an excellent instructor in that he is firm, but fair. However, it's clear that he is spread thin and thus relies heavily on his TAs who made frequent grading errors and were often difficult to reach. There also appeared to be some grading variation (in that some TAs would grant or withhold points for given criteria while others wouldn't).

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
The course workload was intense, but manageable, with some weeks requiring substantially more effort than others. Two of the programming assignments (termed "the beast" and "baby beast") were very difficult, but really forced you to become a competent beginner Java programmer. I credit those two assignments with making many of the programming concepts I didn't understand come together in my mind.

The class was divided between those who had prior programming experience (mainly Python, though we did have some Java programmers as well) and those who didn't. It was my sense that those already familiar with a programming language had an easier time handling the workload that those who didn't.

reviews.content: Really great professor! Blaer is an entertaining, funny lecturer but also explains everything super well and takes the time to answer everyone's questions, no matter how basic, and is very patient. Lectures usually consisted of live coding with an occasional pen and paper to explain concepts. My only complaint would be 1. The TA office hours are always extremely busy, and 2. false promises for grading; when Blaer says to expect grades by a certain date, expect it 2 weeks later. Would really recommend this class!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Homework assignments are half written and half programming. Written ones are usually relatively straightforward, the latter programming ones can be very time consuming taking many hours over 1-2 weeks, but are worth it as they really help you understand the concepts and OOP in Java.

reviews.content:
Taken Fall 2020.

Algorithms, Java, iteration, conditionals, classes, Strings, representing information, Boolean logic, circuits, computer organization, top-down design, arrays, ArrayLists, computer networks, Dijkstra's algorithm, file reading, exceptions, inheritance.

~JW CC'24

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 5 written problem sets, 5 programming projects, 6 in-class exercises, 5 quizzes, no exams.

reviews.content: Prof. Blaer is kind and funny. He is a good person and has big positive energy. Downside? He is not a good lecturer. You will find yourself having to self-learn most if not all of the material. A lot of the people who do good in this class have had prior programming or java experience. If you are a complete beginner, you will struggle! There are TA sessions everyday and Blaer definitely tries his best to help and devote his time.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Workload was manageable 10 hws (textbook and programming). There are textbook readings to fully understand the lectures but they are pretty long and boring.

reviews.content:
Honestly this class was not fun at all. I had taken 1006 in the semester before I took 1004 and I LOVED it... my logic was "omg 1006 was so much fun and I learned a lot with great projects and other assignments so I bet 1004 will be just as helpful and I'm going to learn a lot in java!!!" yeah no. At the beginning the problem sets and programming projects were very easy (which I expected and I'm sure people who were taking this as their first CS class appreciated). But like after the first couple of assignments, the projects just got really repetitive and some of them were dumb hard for an introductory level course. Also Codio is the worst IDE. Why they use it, I have no idea.

The worst part is, that I feel like I barely know anything about java. The only thing I took away from this class is that java uses a lot of semi-colons and brackets? I guess I learned a little bit about the internet and Von Neumann architecture? 

The midterm was straightforward I guess, as was the final (but I took this class during the corona semester so idk what the real final would have looked like).

TLDR; if you're not a CS major and just want a fun intro class, take 1006 or 1002. This class is a lot of work with no reward. I spent an entire semester in the class and I still barely know any java. I used guess and check for the projects (like I would write the code that I think would work, check if it complied, look for the errors which were usually pretty minor syntax errors)

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
5 programming projects (all on Codio) 
5 problem sets (usually written problems, sometimes they have a coding question)
The 10 total assignments lead up to being 40% of your grade-- so do them and do them well and you will probably get an A
1 Midterm (25% of the grade)
1 Final exam (35% of the grade)

This is standard from each semester and the makeup of the class did not change when we went online.

reviews.content: Cannon is great! He clearly cares about his students. Would recommend this course even if you aren't a CS major (if you are willing to put the work in).

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: a lot, but you also learn a lot

reviews.content: I think Cannon was a really good teacher and lecturer. He is entertaining during his lectures, and although he can seem a little unapproachable, he is much less intimidating if you go talk to him during office hours. He also responds to emails quickly if there is a logistics issue. I took AP CS, so the content of the class wasn't that difficult, though there are things to learn even if you did take AP CS, like Turing machines, Dijkstra's algorithm, exception handling, von Neumann architecture, and information about the layers of computer networks. (If you know all of that and took AP CS you could potentially skip to Data Structures, though it was nice to be able to review everything I already knew to really get a firm grip on the material.) I could see the class being a little difficult for people going in with no experience as he doesn't really explain the syntax in depth and you probably will need to do a fair about of self teaching, but conceptually he does a great job explaining everything. I found the midterm and final pretty easy. They were mostly definitions and multiple choice and the final had coding and short answer. Just make sure you pay attention during lecture to all the details. He actually does tell you the answers to some of the harder questions during class. I also really appreciated his organization. Problem sets and projects come out on a timely basis each week. He often codes live for you as well and sends you the code that is done is class, which is helpful.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: A programming project due every other week (5 total), and on the weeks the project is not due, a written pm set (6 total). 1 midterm, and 1 cumulative final.

reviews.content: "A cow says 'moooo.' Right? Are you guys getting this? C'mon. If you're not, you're going to have a hard time on the exam next week."

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.content: Professor Cannon is seriously amazing! He explains hard concepts in a way that is easy to understand. He is also available during office hours and super helpful. I wish I can take more classes with him.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Projects or problem set due almost every week. If I remember correctly, you get the problem set and project at the same time and get a week to complete the problem set, and two weeks for the project. They take some time to complete, but you learn a lot from them.

reviews.content:
Word of warning: only take this class if you are willing to put in the work. You will probably spend at least 8 hours a week on each homework. 

However, it's the class I've felt like I've learned the most at my time at Columbia. It is incredibly rewarding if you like knowledge and new concepts. Do not take for a requirement if you don't care about learning something new. Read through the textbook and go to lectures and you will be okay. 

Cannon is funny and sweet and you can tell he cares a lot about the course. Entertaining lecturer.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
1 homework project or problem set every week.
1 midterm, 1 final.

reviews.content:
Cannon is a very engaging lecturer who explains the material pretty well. His jokes elicit a non-zero amount of laughs consistently, he jokingly thinks the class hates him, and he gives you riddles that have only a tangential relation to the class. 

More importantly, this class provides you with a bunch of background knowledge for CS, moreso than any Java programming proficiency, something that will come in Data Structures. It's a wide breadth with a little depth, but he and the TAs do an admirable job explaining concepts and answering questions, preparing you for the (reasonable) midterm and final.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
HW: It's weighted quite high, with alternating problem sets and programming assignments week by week. You get some credit if your code compiles and if your style is good, which is good if you can't figure something out once in a while.

Midterm: a mixture of term recall and multiple choice, mostly covering concepts in Java and sorting algorithms.

Final: cumulative, terms, multiple choice, and a few short answer problems. If you do way better on the final he will weight the midterm less for you.

reviews.content:
I came into this class having taken a basic programming course in high school.  It wasn't completely a breeze, but very doable and I came through with an A.  With such a basic CS course, there is a lot of information out there if you get lost, and you should utilize it.  The book is very useful, office hours are a big help, there are many resources online, and other students can be helpful with the homeworks if you don't know where to start.  Blaer is a great professor - entertaining, funny, and makes things very clear even when they're difficult concepts to grasp.  Having taken 1004 and 3134 with him, I'm sad to not have him as a professor next semester.

Make sure that you read the book and get help early if you think you might need it - the concepts you'll learn build on each other so it's important to not get lost or it will take a while to get back on track (same with all CS courses, IMO).  If you're new to CS, expect a struggle in the beginning since the most basic concepts are covered pretty quickly, but it will get easier for sure.

Get started on the homework as early as you can and things will go well!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 total homeworks (half programming and half written problems) which often took quite a few hours, midterm and final

reviews.content:
If you have no experience with Java, it's OK. The world is not going to end, but it won't be easy neither. I'm not a fan of reading but Big Java, Late Objects is one of the best books out there to learn Java. I gave my full attention to Blaer, but sometimes I would wonder off. But, it always came to taking some time to read the book and get the hang of it. Some of the answers of the Problem Sets are in the book itself. It's really important and useful that you read the book. Going to recitation doesn't make that much of a difference, unless you want to ask a question. And then again, they may even not answer them, but tell you to wait until Office Hours, since you're not the only one there. 

I had no experience with Java, got an A on the course. I am tech-savy, but it doesn't mean it's not achievable. Once you get the hang of it its pretty awesome! I do recommend taking the course with Paul. He is very funny and very lenient (we got our homework deadline extended like 3 times during the course). 

The problems sets are not that hard. Just make sure you take notes during class so that you can do your homework with them.
Not an "easy A", but its not impossible to get an A.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
11 Problem Sets - varied with just programming, some written, all written, etc. (1 was dropped)
1 Midterm - avg of 106/150 so great curve
Final

reviews.content:
tl;dr: This isn't a easy class if you have no compsci experience. However, if you insist on learning Java, Blaer's the best class to take. Problem sets are a bit of a struggle, exams are reasonable.

Blaer's a fun guy. He's down-to-earth and isn't pretentious. Expect a lot of tangential stories though. There are a lot of TAs, and they're for the most part helpful. Recitation is usually staged more of an OH though, they take questions & don't really have a set plan. You must go to the first recitation--that's when they go through how to set up pico so you can actually code, and it's a million times easier seeing them do it in front of you than trying to read the tutorial.

If you're like me and go into the class w/o knowing any compsci, you're going to spend the first few classes going "what the FUCK is going on." Be good about reviewing notes and reading the textbook though (and doing a lot of googling), and eventually you'll catch up.

Before each exam he'll usually go over what will be tested. Make sure to go to at least one of the TA's review sessions--they'll usually cover something a little more comprehensively than Blaer. Exams are decent. Often I just read & reread the textbook and that was enough. The final covered way more content, but to make up for it it was also easier. 

Also, use Piazza religiously. Questions are almost immediately answered and any question you might have will probably already be up there.

An A is definitely doable, no matter your past experience; you're going to have to put in some work & effort though.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
10 problem sets, half written/half programming. Takes some time.
Midterm 
Final

reviews.content:
If you have previous experience in coding, you most likely will not have trouble with this class. If this is your very first exposure to computer science, be forewarned that this is a challenging class. It will be much more rigorous than most likely any other introductory course in other fields. That being said, if you put in the effort, this class is very doable. You will be spending hours studying, as it requires learning both a language (java) and a general science (CS theory). If you do you not intend to be a computer science major, I would suggest taking a different course that involves coding (like a applications course that teaches Python with another subject, or a coding course for nonmajors). If you do take this course, be prepared to do a lot of googling & research on your own to figure out how Java works. It would really help you to do some basic tutorials to get the gist of it before you head into the first lecture. 

Blaer is an excellent professor, and his explanatory style is very clear and concise. He gets very distracted in his lectures, and it's pretty hilarious and adorable--which always made them a pleasure to attend. His expectations for tests and homeworks are always very clear. He does, however, have a tendency to underemphasize how difficult/important topics will be. For example, when listing topics to go over on test, if he mentions something in passing, you should know it pretty much backwards and forwards. Another example, the second to last homework we used a hashmaps, FileReaders, and PrinterWriters--all of which he probably talked about for like two seconds and never explained. 

Additionally, the TAs are beautiful, wonderful human beings. James Lin the head TA/(and I quote) "aspiring Little League Coach" is the best thing to happen to 1004 probably ever, and he was very encouraging and generally super kind in all his emails and communications. They are all very helpful, just be sure to find one who you get along with and remember their office hours (there are like a 11 TAs, and like always office hours). Piazza is also a great resource, with under 15 min response times. Usually all of my questions were already answered there before I even needed to ask anyone.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 total homeworks, half programming and half written problems (basically one a week). Both are challenging, although the relatively diffictulty from one assignment to the next varies greatly. Allow yourself the time to fully explore them. Recitations are largely unnecessary/extra. One midterm, one final.

reviews.content:
Definitely take this class. Blaer is incredible and hilarious. You don't really need to go to the lectures to understand this, especially because the book does a great job of explaining it but its good to go just to hear Blaer talk. The class is not too difficult and is a great introduction to Java, very interesting and I learned a lot. If you are on the fence about it you should for sure take the class.

The homework assignments can be challenging sometimes but he gives you a ton of time to do them and there are so many TA's for this class that it makes everything very doable.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 1 midterm 1 final ~9 homework assignments

reviews.content:
Be warned: Cannon does not hold your hand. He assumes that everyone in the class is wicked smaht and tailors his lectures, assignments, and exams accordingly.

But I strongly disagree with the reviewer below. I walked into Cannon's class with no programming background, but I found his class enjoyable and occasionally challenging. The only prerequisite you need to succeed in Cannon's class is good time management.

Start on your assignments early, and ask questions on Piazza or during office hours when you get stuck. Read the assigned chapters BEFORE you go to lectures: Cannon does an excellent job clarifying tricky material in class.

Aim for comprehension - make a serious effort to understand difficult concepts as well as your mistakes on the assignments - and you will do very well in this class.

--

I do agree about what the other reviewer said about the TAs. The VAST majority of them, especially Zoe and Anusha, are just the sweetest people you'll meet on this planet, but yes, a few of them are unbelievably rude and disgustingly condescending.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 Problem Sets, 5 Programming Projects, 1 Midterm, 1 Final

reviews.content:
I imagine this class would be very difficult to succeed in with no programming background.  I took AP Computer Science in high school, so I expected Cannon's class to be cake.  However, it still did require a good deal of effort and I felt appropriately challenged throughout the semester.  As past reviewers have mentioned, the learning curve is pretty steep, with problem set 1, and programming projects 2-4 being among the most stressful.  Cannon is not kidding when he says that the programming projects will require 10+ hours of work -- they really do!  Your best bet would be to start early on the projects and attend TA office hours whenever you hit a major rut.  

Lectures are helpful, but only as a brief summary of what you need to know.  To rely on lectures alone would leave you poorly prepared for the assignments in this class, but I think that for any technical class this goes without saying.  The two recommended textbooks are both very good resources and will be relied on heavily throughout the course.  I found that the lectures and problem sets were representative of exam content.  The programming projects, however, were not.  

The class is well organized, with a very clear outline of covered topics and assigned grading groups to expedite grading.  There is an entire army of TAs who rotate on a schedule to grade your problem sets/programming projects and who send you detailed grade reports VIA lionmail (more on the TAs later...).

Overall, I think the course does a good job at its ambitious task of introducing students to the fundamentals of computer science and programming in Java.  In addition, you will also be introduced to software like: Pico, CUnix, CyberDuck, Eclipse, Vagrant VirtualBox (maybe), and Gimp.  Professor Cannon has a good sense of humor and tries to make even the duller aspects of computer science interesting.  If you commit yourself to doing all the work, the takeaway is enormous.  My only major complaint:

THE TAs (well, some of them):

The TAs are a mixed lot.  Some are truly wonderful and are willing to help you with all your NullPointerExceptions, while others seem plain butthurt about losing points for inane reasons back when they were COMS W1004 students.  Between the 6 problem sets and 5 programming projects, you'll come into contact with at least 11 of the TAs.  

As I mentioned earlier, your grade reports are sent to your lionmail by your TA of the week.  Frequently, students will respond to the grade report emails to ask for suggestions or for a more detailed explanation of how to improve code.  As I have heard from other students, and as I have experienced myself, this sometimes results in the TAs correcting your grade to a lower score.  What I mean is this: when the TA sees your grade report again in your reply email, they might see that they made a mistake in grading you and then will lower your score by the appropriate amount.  

Until the TAs start grading things without error, or until some sort of "grade-is-set-after-sending-to-student" policy is put into place, you should not ask the TA who graded you for pointers.  I repeat DO NOT ASK THE TA WHO GRADED YOUR ASSIGNMENT ABOUT THE ASSIGNMENT--THEY MIGHT SPOT SOMETHING THEY DIDN'T TAKE OFF POINTS FOR AND THEN PROCEED TO TAKE OFF POINTS FOR IT.

To me this seems rather messed up.  Isn't the best person to learn from the professional who was paid to read through every line of your code?  As things currently are, it is impractical to talk to this person because they could easily spot a mistake in their grading and then make a last-minute change on CourseWorks.  In no other class I've ever taken in my academic career have assignment grades been so impermanent.  I overheard other students in the help room speak of "avoiding" the TA that graded their most recent assignment in fear that they could have points deducted.  I hate to think I could have done better in this class by NOT asking the person who graded my assignment for help...

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
6 problem sets (cover various aspects of computer science) - take about 2-4 hours 

5-6 programming projects - take 15+ hours (not including time spent on the optional extra credit portions) 

familiarizing yourself with Pico, CUnix, CyberDuck, Eclipse, Vagrant VirtualBox, and Gimp - time varies

~50 vocab terms to memorize for midterm

~100 vocab terms to memorize for final (lots of overlap with midterm terms)

midterm exam with vocab terms and multiple choice q's

final exam with vocab terms and multiple choice q's

reviews.content:
If you are taking computer science first time and have had very little or no experience with programming, you will have a tough time in the class. Cannon's lectures on the programming component aren't helpful at all; the best way to deal with programming assignments is to start early, read the Big Java book, and attend office hours. 

His lectures on the conceptual component of Computer Science are useful, though reading the book would give you the same information, but it can be more time consuming since it has a lot of unnecessary information.

His first midterm includes a lot of memorization and not a lot of programming examples. The programming component isn't related to the assignments at all but to the simple principles of object-oriented programming. The other component was mostly memorization. (There were questions asking the size of the 'short' data type, for instance.) The final has less questions based on memorization and can help you bump your grade since it's as long as the midterm.

He makes a lot of trashy jokes that most people seem to like. He also wastes a lot of time on unnecessary questions such as "I would like to major in Computer Science; when should I take Discrete Math?" in class. His lectures are very unfocused, and you can do fine even if you skipped some lectures. How you do in the class depends more on you and very little on lectures.

I still do not understand why he is in charge of all the introductory computer science classes when he cannot clarify basic but important concepts.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
6 problem sets - very hard to get full points on
5 programming assignments - takes a lot of time, TAs will pay attention to silly things like whether you used spaces
1 midterm - lots of memorization
1 final

reviews.content: If you've never had any programming/Computer Science, your first class will be a bit rough, but Cannon warns his students of this. For me, the first month or two were not too challenging, but mid-semester I hit a wall. Try to to the TAs before you feel confused, and if you feel the slightest bit confused, definitely go the TA or get a tutor. Makes life much easier in the long-run. Cannon is a great lecturer (especially for python!) and throws in a good number of jokes (that are actually funny!!) He is approachable and tries to make his introductory classes challenging for all but also accessible to people who aren't taking his class for the major. He also stresses the importance of improvement, and is willing to work with you if you scored really badly on the midterm as long as you improve on the final. The TAs for both intro. classes are great! For Java, study your vocab. A LOT.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Programming Project or Problem Set (only in Java, not Python) every two weeks. Midterm and Final.

reviews.content:
I was apprehensive about taking this course since I had no experience with programming or computer science.

As I look back on this semester, I have come to the conclusion that yes, it is possible to take this course without prior knowledge of programming. However, it will require a lot of work on your part. If you're up for a challenge, this is the course for you.

In terms of personality, Cannon is quite friendly and cracks pretty good jokes in lecture. In his office hours, I found Cannon to be quite helpful and not at all sarcastic, in contrast to what other reviewers have said (but that might be because I came on a day in which very few students were asking him for help). 

Cannon is a decent lecturer, although he goes through concepts and examples very quickly. If you don't ask questions or follow up his lectures with your reading, you will get left behind. Be sure that you keep up at all times! (also, the textbooks for this class are quite helpful).

For problem sets and programming projects, do not procrastinate! They take much more time than you think they do (he's not kidding when he says that the class will require at least nine hours of work per week). If you get stuck, go to office hours, ask a CS friend, or use Piazza (the online messaging board) to get your questions answered. 

Overall, I'm glad that I took this course. It was challenging and I might not get the grade I want, but I'm glad that I learned something new.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Each problem set is due after a week and each programming project is due after two weeks. Get started ASAP and make sure you do a little bit of work each day!

Midterm and final are difficult. Make sure you review the code presented in class (he might present a different version of a concept than in the book, so that's an added incentive to go to class) and read the books!

reviews.content: If you're only going to take one Comp Sci course take Java with Professor Cannon. He is fully aware that most people have never coded before and provides very structured ways to allow people to easily understand coding. He doesn't start off too quickly and provides tons of sample code which is usually very similar to the homework he gives. He is very open to peoples comments and asks for questions. Probably one of the best classes I've taken at college so far.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Alternating programming problem sets and written problem sets every week. Anywhere from 2-8 hours for the programming problem sets depending on how comfortable you are with the topic. About 2-3 hours for the written problem sets

reviews.content:
Adam Cannon is a pretty solid teacher. He knows his stuff, and is very organized when teaching. With this in mind, Intro to Java is probably one of the most challenging and time-consuming classes offered at Columbia. Unless you have to take this class for your major, be sure you REALLY want to take this class. There are much easier ways to learn coding and Java. When Cannon tells you at the beginning that this class will take at least 10 hours of work per week, he is telling the truth. Many times, the work requires a lot more than 10 hours/week. 

There is a lot of information that Cannon tries to teach in this course. You will learn both theory and programming in this class. Because of the amount of info he tries to teach, Cannon skips over a lot of basic stuff that he expects you to learn on your own. I had no experience in programming coming in so I wish he would not have skipped over stuff. For this reason, I would only recommend this class to someone who has some experience or background in coding. Talking to many who were in the same boat as me, we had to play catch-up throughout the semester. This class is already considered difficult to those with coding backgrounds, so it makes life even more miserable when you have to put even more work into an already difficult class.

The TAs for the class are usually pretty helpful. I would recommend getting help from the TA that grades your assignments since some of the grading, especially the written assignments, can be very subjective. I also went to Cannon's office hours. He does not come off as the nicest or most personable person ever, but he does try to help you out. He definitely does not try or care to get to know students (at least in this class). I will give him props for his cheesy jokes that lighten up the class.

In the end, you really have to decide if you are willing to do the work for the class. If you just want to take this class because you think coding will be "fun" to learn, do not take the class. Learn coding on your own at a pace where it can be fun, exciting, and addictive. Besides those who are majoring in CS, only those who are serious about learning Java and the theory of programming in a rigorous and often cutthroat setting should take this class.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
The HW alternates between a programming assignment and written assignment. 1 midterm and 1 final. At least 10 hours/week is needed to do well in the class. Make sure you read the textbooks since he glosses over some stuff in class. Attendance is not mandatory, but you're only screwing yourself over if you skip classes.

Heavy Workload

reviews.content:
Funny in class. Kind of mean in office hours. A fair grader. TAs in this class really care and are helpful. However, going to a TA other than the one who is going to grade your problem set is usually a waste of time because the open-ended short answer problems are subjectively and sometimes harshly graded. For programming assignments, all the TAs are amazing and Cannon gives good advice during class. 

Also there is a generous curve at the end, which is to be expected in a class of 200+ people

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Heavy. Start early. Do all the reading. This class has more reading than two science classes combined, but the book is really helpful. If you do not read, you will not do well on the midterm or final.

reviews.content:
Well, he already has his silver nugget, but let it be said: Cannon deserves it. His lectures are fun to go to, and he tries really hard. I usually feel bad when people don't laugh at his dumb jokes so I laugh pretty hard to give him some credit. I usually enjoyed going to lecture. I never brought my computer, though, because all his example code is posted on courseworks anyway. You can do your note-taking just as well in a traditional notebook, and if you know that you are easily distracted, I'd recommend not bringing a computer. The two lectures that I did bring one I may as well not even have showed up because I have no idea what happened.

The course itself is hard, for sure. This class is an introduction CS and programming class, so if you never took AP Computer Science in high school, you're going into a topic that you've literally never seen before, unlike most of your other classes. It's pretty satisfying, though, when a few weeks in you're already writing simple programs that can do tasks that you couldn't do a few weeks before.

The programming assignments are tough, especially compared to the homework which literally take maybe 1-2 hours tops. Programming takes probably 10ish hours. The singular most important advice is go to the TA office hours. There are like 8 TAs for the class. Obviously the TA hours the day before your assignment is due are going to be packed, so try to go earlier if you can. The ones in the middle of the week are literally empty so you could have one-on-one time to do your work with a TA sitting right there who sole purpose is to answer any questions you have and help with your programming.

Cannon also sets up an account for the class on this website, Piazza.com, that is basically a messaging board where people can ask questions and the TAs, other students and Cannon (occasionally) can answer questions. This is a really good resource because your question has almost always been asked by someone else, and you can ask questions anonymously.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 1 programming assignment every other week (10 hours give or take 2 or 3), 1 homework every other week (1-3 hours), 1 midterm, 1 final. Midterm is multiple choice, definitions, a section of code to debug, and an algorithm with questions about it. Final from what I understand (class isn't finished yet) is the same as midterm with more multiple choice.

reviews.content:
I actually took this class last year, spring semester but haven't got a chance to review it yet. Let me just say that there aren't many classes I'd actually feel obligated to review, but this is definitely one of them.

This is so far the best class I've taken at Columbia. This class gives you a great overview of Computer Science, and an unmatched introduction to programming. Somehow Cannon manages to fit in a ton of material while still giving a good sense of each topic. The only exception to this would be the section of the class on computer networks, which I honestly feel could have been narrowed down to just the information about internet protocols. 

Learning object-oriented programming has a learning curve, but once you've got it, you're just coasting from then on. That's not to say projects don't take a while -- you'll spend hours trying to find bugs in your program. But in general, I think there's only a few concepts in this class that are difficult to learn, the main one being OOP. Nonetheless, Cannon and the TAs make themselves pretty available to you, and the assignments are not unreasonable. That being said, pay attention to what Cannon says: if he wants you to understand a concept by a certain homework (e.g. what objects are) you should do it, and you'll be fine.

I think the main idea I want to convey with this review is that the work you do, while heavy, is very meaningful, and you'll learn a lot about algorithmic problem solving and programming in Java.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: As mentioned, pretty heavy, but the work you're given is very meaningful, and you'll have a far elevated understanding of programming and CS by the end of the course. Tests have tricks here and there, but if you understand the concepts they're pretty easy. I finished the final in about half the time.

reviews.content: This course was difficult for sure.  There was a lot of learning on oneâ€™s own simply because there was so much material, but there were resources there for use that could make oneâ€™s life a whole lot easier, such as TAs.  This is where I have to disagree with the previous reviewer.  Madhavan was a standout TA.  He stayed after his office hours by as much as three hours one time because people needed help.  When he was in the TA room attending office hours for his own CompSci classes, he would help 1004 kids who needed help.  No matter how many people came he would individually go through his studentsâ€™ code to find problems big and small.  He also didnâ€™t treat students who didnâ€™t know things like idiots which is more than can be said for some others of the TAs.  I would know, I went to pretty much every TAâ€™s office hours.  Madhavan was not an easy grader, but thatâ€™s because he knows his stuff and demands a high standard; if you donâ€™t want to be held to a high standard, donâ€™t go to Columbia.  The TA Matt was also awesome though he wasnâ€™t my primary TA so I donâ€™t know his grading styleâ€¦  Cannon was helpful but impersonal, class of 300â€¦  You will feel accomplished after taking this class, but donâ€™t expect to sail.  But classes like this are why you come to Columbia, you work hard as hell, and then you get a ton out of it.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Punishing, but worth it.  Alternating problem sets and programming assignments.  Exams are straightforward and managable.  You do the time, and you will be ok.  Don't assume you are smart and will be fine.  Cannon says the first day of class, Engineers are made not born...

reviews.content:
When you enroll into this "Intro" to Java class, you are signing yourself up for a scheduled butt-kicking every time a programming assignment is due. 

Do yourself a favor and start the programming assignments early, and write down all your questions so that you can meet with the TA's during office hours to sort it out. 

Cannon is a fantastic teacher and he is very talented at keeping the entire class attentive during lecture. Take notes during class, because he only covers the important material, which makes sense, because that is exactly what appears on the midterm/final.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Homeworks worth 40% (2-3 from one Textbook, 2-3 from another Textbook, and 5-6 programming assignments), a midterm worth 25%, and a final worth 35%.

reviews.content:
Cannon is great. He's an interesting lecturer (hilarious, and also super passionate), very receptive if you ever want to meet, has tons of office hours, and is always very fair. Also, he has tons of (useful) TA's, so basically there is always someone available whenever you need help on homework, including weekends. 

I had some experience with programming before taking this class, but I had to put a sizable amount of work into this class--the programming assignments take time. (But really, start early. The TA's can basically help you through any problems you're having if you go to office hours.) 

That being said, this class made me want to be a computer science major. It's incredibly fun and satisfying, and was definitely my favorite class this semester.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
An assignment every week alternating between a problem set, which should take maybe an hour or two, and a programming assignment, which can take between 2-10 hours. This class really is manageable, as long as you start early and get help--people who say it took them 20 hours a week probably started homework due Monday on a Friday.

One midterm, one final, both very straightforward---if you do the readings and understand what he's talking about in class, you'll be fine.

reviews.content:
I am not a computer science major or a computer science person at all; I'm not a math or science or logic person in any sense of any of those terms. My mind just doesn't work that way, and I struggled with this class more than I've struggled with any other class.

That being said, it was probably my favorite class thus far. Cannon is just a wonderful man who makes the lectures interesting, fun, and clear. He is incredibly welcoming ad supportive, so absolutely take advantage of his office hours. Talk to him about any concerns that you have - whether it's a specific coding problem or worries about the class in general - and he will help you. 

If you're not a computer science person, there is a lower level class that provides a lot of the background for this class, which I didn't know about, and could have done much better had I taken it. This is not an easy class, but it's very fulfilling. It's something I never could have seen myself doing, but I would absolutely recommend taking it.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
It's pretty tough. You definitely have to put the work in. Everything is doable, even if you don't have the familiarity in programming that a good majority of the class does. You'll be surprised at how capable you become, and this is one of the few classes where you are actually proud of your work and have something to show for it.
Tests are absolutely straightforward but you need to have a very deep understanding of the material. If you do all along, you won't need to study much, but if you are struggling, you'll need to put in a lot of time.

reviews.content:
Cannon is a phenomenal teacher.  If you're not interested in computer science, go to class just because it's fun.  Since it is an INTRO course to computer science and java, he does a really great job at explaining concepts, etc. and will happily answer any question.  You will learn so much more from being in class than by reading the textbook.

That being said, read the textbook and make notes!  The midterm and final both include a vocabulary section - where you have to write a definition for the given words (note, Cannon gave us a list of 100 possible terms for the final and tested us on 10).

The midterm is really easy if you're prepared.  Do the work, meet with TA's, etc. etc. etc.

The programming assignments will take a lot of time, so definitely do NOT start the night before they are due.

Let me say again - Cannon is a phenomenal teacher.  He is an amazing lecturer and makes class fun.  He always has a good story, funny / snide remark, or riddle / brainteaser to share.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: An assignment every week alternating between a written assignment (problems in the textbook) that is generally quite easy - and a programming assignment that is generally quite difficulty.  One midterm, one final.

reviews.content:
Cannon is a great lecturer. He's very clear and has the wonderful ability to see things from a student's perspective. I believe he's been teaching this class for several years, every semester and so the class is well-planned and thought out.

I would recommend going to all the lectures, you'll really learn a lot and also you probably won't have to spend much time reading Big Java for the assignments if you attend class. Plus Cannon always goes on random CS-related tangents every once in a while and these are generally fun and informative.

As for the class, it's got two components; theory (Intro to CS) and programming (Intro to Java). Theory and programming homeworks alternate from week to week. Theory homeworks are not too bad, they can be done just from reading the relevant chapters in the book. Programming ones can be challenging and take varying amounts of time (depending on who you are) but you will certainly learn how to program at the end of it.

Midterm and final aren't all that bad if you've been keeping up with the lectures and the homeworks. They're a bit on the memorization side of things - especially the final which asked some pretty obscure questions which is why it's good to attend lecture because he often mentions random things that I noticed ended up on the test.

I should mention that although this is intro CS, it's a pretty high level intro so don't take the class for the granted - you'll have to put in some work to get an A.

Also there are lots of office hours and for the most part the TAs are great so I would highly recommend popping in if you have question regarding your assignment; even if you code works, you might wanna just make sure with the TAs that your design, etc. is okay.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: See above.

reviews.content:
