This is the class that made me want to major in Computer Science. At first I only took it because it was a requirement, but Adam Cannon is a skilled lecturer. He knows how to make confusing material digestible, and his classes are enjoyable.

I would recommend going to office hours - the TAs are generally pretty helpful, and it's useful to get feedback on your code before you submit it.

The programming assignments were a lot of fun, once you get into them. The book assignments (the theoretical ones) can be a pain, but they're necessary to grasp the material fully.

It's not necessarily the easiest class that you'll take at Columbia (unless you're already a programmer and therefore shouldn't be taking this class anyway). But it's also not the hardest - and it may even be the best and most important one you take. Make sure you take this class.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 assignments, each with a programming part and a theoretical part. One midterm and one final (both easier than they could be, but you still need to study for them - means are in the 70s). Mean is curved to a "high-B, not a B+" (in his words).

reviews.content: Cannon is awesome. With a couple of masters degrees and a phd, you know he's incredibly smart, but he also keeps the class moving well with his wit. Class attendance is typically helpful, but you can get by for most topics by simply doing the assigned reading. If you do attend class, supplementation with assigned reading is still ideal. The texts for the class are pricey so get them from a friend or rent them if possible. Only one of the two, Big Java, will really be useful after the course is over, so if there's one to buy, that's it. The books are thick, but the course does not cover nearly all the chapters in them.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: This class necessitates a tremendous amount of effort and time, but it's totally worth it. The satisfaction of realizing the efficiency and power of a program you've just designed and built is unbelievable after you've spent hours debugging it. The class alternates a theoretical problem set from the book every other week with a programming project every other week. The problem sets are generally pretty simple and graded fairly, with the programming assignments much harder but graded fairly easily. The midterm and final were extremely easy, and the class is curved to something like a B+ average.

reviews.content: A good teacher. I had zero comp sci background and am doing fine in the class, he's awesome at office hours and explains things really well. A lot of people who complain about the workload also start the assignments really late, which is a bad idea. A great class and a funny teacher, i enjoyed it.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
can be a lot at times, take his advice- if you haven't made in progress in half an hour stop and get help.
book questions can be a drag but are pretty easy

reviews.content:
This class the truly Terrible and unbelievably hard! It says that it is an into level class, but its not. This was the most time consuming, annoying and frustrating class I have ever taken. If you have taken AP comp sci, or have a better idea of java you will be struggling, but if you have none DO NOT TAKE! It was impossible with out outside help. 

Cannon is a funny man, and class was not boring, but the subject is just impossible. The theory stuff is easy and understandable but the java is very very hard and is not taught at all, its more teach yourself everything or find someone who knows what they are doing and have them teach you. 
I learned ALOT, but in the end, not worth it.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 4 Programming Assignments, all pretty much impossible, but very rewarding when you finish them. Don't expect to do that well on them (close to 20 hours of work for each). 4 theory problem sets, more managable but still time consuming. Midterm and final, easier than programming assignments but still VERY hard and painful.

reviews.content: Ms. Leslie is a very sweet teacher. She's very young, and she's very approachable. She will give you all the time in the world if you need help understanding something. She presents all her lessons well, using powerpoint presentations. Good speaker. I took the class with no programming experience as a freshman, and got an A. I did, however, go to her office hours every week, so she got to know me and I did get extra review. But I wouldn't do the assigned readings, and usually didn't pay good attention in class. Programming is fun, but sometimes frustrating when you don't see your mistake. She will extend deadlines if everyone is behind.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: moderate

reviews.content: The first day of class Professor Cannon told us we should expect to be spending at least 10 hours a week doing work for the course. I thought he was joking. HE WAS NOT. This is a great class and he's pretty good at explaining concepts (if you pay attention), and he's understanding about extensions and going over certain topics more in-depth if the class needs it. But the weekly assignments were pretty difficult and/or very time-consuming. You MUST start each assignment at least 4-5 days before the due date, because you will run into problems with your programs and you need time to meet with the TA's. I found that many students taking the class had prior programming experience and they found it easier (and messed up the curve). But for the rest of us it was a grueling learning experience. I'm glad to have taken it but you need to invest time, no joke.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Weekly assignments, alternating between theory and programming. One midterm and one final. The average for the midterm was like 87 or something. The final was harder. STUDY.

reviews.content:
I was very happy to see Professor Cannon has a star, which I think he deserves.  COMS W1004 could be one of the best courses at Columbia.  I would recommend this course to any strong student up for a challenge, even one who does not need COMS as a requirement.  Professor Cannon says it is not easy and tells us which assignments are especially hard, but CS will teach you a new way of thinking about the world.  Professor Cannon covers the basics of both hardware (the physical structure of the computer) and programming, so by the time you're done with the course you will probably know which topic you like better.  Lectures supplemented the readings and helped clarify which aspects of the materials were the most important.  One of Professor Cannon's strengths was making complicated concepts understandable.  He is willing to go over the same idea more than once, even at the expense of glossing over a few simpler programming concepts that I would have liked the lectures and assignments to cover a bit more thoroughly.  The final was DEFINITELY harder than the midterm, although neither was excessively difficult.

It's a good idea for people without a very strong programming/hardware background to take W1004--you learn quite a bit about both and are a much more fluid programmer by the time you reach the more advanced courses.  Professor Cannon was very good at introducing us to the academic organizations and resources the CS department offers.

The fact that there are many TAs means that you should be able to come to a good TA's office hours (in my experience, decent to good TAing was the rule rather than the exception).  Professor Cannon is also accessible and reasonably flexible.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: THIS COURSE IS NOT A JOKE!!!  For me, the workload was 5-18 hours a week.  Start readings, assignments and exam studying at least 4 days early, because you don't know how long it will take to understand a concept or get a program to work.

reviews.content: Paul Blaer is a master in his field. He knows exactly what he is doing, and can answer damn near any question you can come up with. The homework assignments are not extremely difficult, but do take time and actual mastery of the subject. He makes himself very available if you need help, and has knowledge of Computer Science that extends far beyond Java. The workload is not serious, and you do not really need to attend lecture if you're keeping up with the book. However, it doesn't hurt your grade at all to attend lecture, as he often gives clarification on confusing topics and a myriad of extra information which could help you out on the midterm and final.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Five (5) homework assignments, each worth 10% of your grade. They are not difficult. One (1) midterm, fairly difficult, make sure you know your theory. One (1) final.

reviews.content: This class was a huge time sink.  I was up all night for three of the programming assignments, and I did not miss class (although most did).  Professor Aho does have difficulty explaining things in a way that varies from his lesson plan.  He did cover the material, that is about the best you can say.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: HIGH.  Nuff said.

reviews.content: I don't think the previous two reviews are fair, Shlomo is one of the few teachers that I've had who really cares about improving his class and helping students. Although some lectures can be a little bland, I found the homeworks to be pretty interesting and helpful getting to know how to use CS skills in more useful applications than 1004.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 homeworks (but only ended up having 4 assigned), fair midterm and lots of extra credit.

reviews.content: Prof. Cannon is awesome. He tries to make the course interesting and makes a ton of jokes. He wants everyone to do well and really makes it easy for you. The TA sessions are really helpful. If you put in the work you can def. get an A and you might even find yourself more interested in comp. sci. after a course with him

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
homeworks-- not bad and if you do them they count a lot and can help your grade.
midterm/final, pretty straightforward with no suprises

reviews.content: This is supposed to be an intro class, but Aho made it too hard for people with out experience.  He is a brilliant man, but unless you already know a lot about comp sci, you are about to get totally screwed over.  TA's didn't even know how to solve all of the hw problems.  This class was torture to me.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Too much.  Way too much.

reviews.content: Janak is by far the best professor I've had at Columbia. Not only did he take the time to learn practically everyone's name, he also was an excellent lecturer. His class is very understandable and helpful in both the basics of computers and in begining to think about how computers operate. As an added bonus, he brought in doughnuts on the day of the final to makeup for the 9:00am exam time.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Six homeworks worth 50% of the grade, more like small projects with both a written and a programming part. A midterm (17%) and a final (33%) both moderatly difficult. Grading is fair, and extra credit opportunites exist.

reviews.content: Janak is one of the most student-friendly professors at Columbia, and a very good teacher.  The class is essentially half introductory theory, and half intro to java programming.  Janak designs it to be the kind of class that ANYONE can succeed in easily as long as they try.  Just go to class, take decent notes, and you will have everything you need to do the homeworks and tests without breaking a sweat.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 Homeworks, the last two of which were pretty difficult.  The homework counts for 50% of the grade.  Midterm and final were somewhat predictable and not too rough.

reviews.content: Like everyone else has said, Janak is really great. He doesn't try to screw you over on the midterms and finals - all the work is very much doable with little difficulty (if not, it's not hard to get help). He also gave out extra credit assignments in class. He genuinely wants people to do well. If you're going to take this class, Janak is definitely a good choice.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 HW's (every other week, total 150 points), 1 midterm (50 points), final (100 points)

reviews.content: This class was absolutely rediculous.  I'm lucky I passed.  The homwork was so hard that sometimes the TA's couldnt help.  He expects a lot from you and because he is so smart, his whole level of thinking is way beyond us humans.  He's a genius robot that shouldn't be in the class room.  I respect his mind, but hes a bad professor.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Excessive bi-weekly assignments, hard midterm, harder exam.  Bad curve.

reviews.content: He is very nice and interesting, but I feel that everything he says in class is posted online  which makes coming sort of pointless.  His midterm was very easy and the final was very hard.  The homeworks ranged from easy to hard.  There was not much of a curve in the final grade.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Homeworks are 25 percent of grade, problem sets are 25 percent, midterm is 25 percent and final is 25 percent.   This class should take up a LOT of your time (all you first years will not need to worry about being bored)

reviews.content: Professor Stavrou took the sting out of learning how to work with computers.   I recommend this class to anyone that wants to learn how to create web pages or really use Microsoft Excel on a higher level.  He's a fair grader and extremely patient with those of us that are not very computer saavy.  He responds to emails promptly, offers extra credit opportunities, and is generally available to students for extra help.  He will work with advanced students and create more challenging projects for them if the rest of the class is holding them back.   Although this is the most basic CS course offered at Columbia, we're writing Javascript Programs already.  This class has given me great practical skills that I will utilize in the workplace after I graduate.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Midterm (not exactly easy) and Final Exam.  BiWeekly Homework Projects.

reviews.content: Janak is a great guy! He attended Columbia so he can relate to our classes. He really cares about the students and tries to be as exciting and fair as possible. You will learn a lot in his class and also receive a good grade if you put forth an effort!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Homework (both theory and programming) every other week, 6 in total..midterm (very easy), final (somewhat challenging)..midterm and final open book and open notes!!

reviews.content: Out of the 25+ professors I have had, Professor Cannon is probably one of the WORST professors I have ever had.  He's a very nice person but he is awful at instructing and clearly explaining the course material.  He does not provide a syllabus, which I feel is helpful when reviewing for the course.  This course is an INTRODUCTION course which means NOT EVERYONE enrolled in the course has has prior experience with Computer Science.  He quickly covers each topic providing a few very easy examples and then excepts you to be a professional programmer on the projects and exams.  Stay away from this class unless you have to take it for a requirement . . . I did the mistake of taking this class because I thought it would be "interesting."  I haven't learned anything!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Five HW assignments -- pretty difficult and you don't feel prepared for any of them . . . unless of course you have had experience with Computer Science before.  One midterm exam and one final exam (comprehensive), again , difficult if you have no background.  He does curve grades.

reviews.content: Thank god they opened up an introductory computer science course for the non computer science major. If you're not planning on majoring in comp sci, I advise taking this introductory course as opposed to CS1007. At the beginning of the course I thought Prof. Leslie was the worst teacher on the face of the earth, but then I realized that Comp Sci is just the worst subject on the face of the earth and that she is actually a pretty good teacher. She clearly presents ideas that are very complicated to understand. Her lessons are very structured and she makes the material as simple to understand as it can possibly be. Don't be alarmed if your a bit confused for the first 2 or 3 weeks, because if you've had no comp sci background (much like I had none when taking this course) it takes a little while to get used to the concepts. Prof. Leslie is an excellent teacher, although she is a bit nervous up there (i.e.: she laughs a lot when she talks and she writes EVERYTHING she says on the board!!!!! (in other words, if she says, "It's sunny today" you better believe it'll be up on the blackboard")). She is also very approachable and extremely understanding. So besides needing to relax a little, she is a great teacher, and she made comp sci bareable for someone (aka: me) who HATES comp sci with a passion.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 6 homeworks: 1 due every 2 weeks. (they are long, but doable, so start early) COUNTS AS 50% OF YOUR GRADE SO TAKE THE TIME TO DO THEM WELL!!!! One midterm: 15% of grade and the final: 35% of grade. Fair tests.

course.name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content: lectures aren't recorded but he posts his notes before each class, so you can download the jupyter notebook file and follow along with his example code in class and also play around with the code yourself. he teaches topics at a reasonable pace and at the start of each class, he does a brief review of material covered in the previous class. overall, he's a very very nice guy

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
1 exercise set every 2-3 wks: 3 total, graded on completion. each consists of 3-4 free response questions and 3-4 coding problems, some are pretty fun! (e.g. hangman, blackjack) if you just sit down one day and lock in on it, you could get it done in 2-4 hours.
3 group projects (3 people, you can fill out a form to choose your group member preferences): present to a TA by explaining your code, takes a considerable amount of time (collectively, 10 hrs? maybe more) so don't procrastinate and keep reminding your group to get their stuff done.
3 midterms, no final: midterms are 6 FRQs and not overly challenging, partial credit given, he provides a list of topics and goes over them during the class before the midterm

reviews.content: I expected this class to be more beginner friendly than it was. I came from no experience. It was alright, and I did manage to do well, however, it took a lottt of practice outside of class and finding resources on my own. While Bauer is a super nice guy and really wants all his students to succeed, I also did not understand his method of teaching. It seems more example heavy than overarching rule heavy (which is how I learn to apply to other examples). Still, his class was fair, just I felt that I struggled a lot in it.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: 4 problem sets, 3 midterms (the final is technically a midterms), and 3 group projects contributed to your grade. This class was not a huge time commitment at all if you didn't need extensive practice outside of class. For me, I found that I did need that extra practice, however, the work actually assigned to me was super manageable.

reviews.content:
Professor Bauer is a warm and kind person who creates a welcoming environment for all kinds of questions. He’s always available to answer them, whether in class, during office hours, or on Ed. He also has a large team of TAs, so if you’re struggling with a concept, there’s plenty of support available. He’s also very understanding and approachable.
The class is well-organized. He uses Jupyter Notebook (which he posts after class) for lectures and runs code on it to demonstrate concepts step by step. During lectures, he’s happy to answer questions, (even after class too).
The homework and projects aren’t too difficult, but it’s important to start early to give yourself time to think through them and ask questions if needed. The homework does a good job of preparing you for the types of questions he gives on exams. He dedicates an entire class to review before each exam, which is really helpful.

Lectures can sometimes feel a bit dry, and I found myself nearly falling asleep a few times. Also, exams and PSets take too long to grade.

Overall, Professor Bauer is a great instructor who cares about his students and provides plenty of resources to help them succeed.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
4 Individual Exercise Sets (ES) ->	20% (5% each, material covered in class)
3 Group Projects -> 24% (8% each) (You work in a group of 3 that you can choose. Start early so that you have time to ask questions. After submitting, you need to present the project to a TA. The TAs are chill)
3 Exams -> 54% (18% each, as the last one is final) (Start early, go over the lectures and the review done in class. He also provides you with a list of topics included. The final was really tough, while the first two exams were fair. He might curve if needed)
Exercise Set 0	-> 2%

reviews.content: I took Intro to Computing for EAS Spring 2022, and I thought I had a good experience. It served as a nice precursor to programming (in Python, specifically) and I appreciated the opportunities we had to learn about different concepts about the language and its accompanying libraries. The policies for the course were also very lenient. I got two extensions on my assignments since I was busy with work from other classes. I would recommend this course as an elective if you’re not a SEAS major (since I understand it’s required for SEAS students). Admittedly, Professor Paine could have been more engaging in the lectures, as I often found myself not attending since the content was relatively simple for me to grasp, and I didn’t enjoy sitting in for the lectures much.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: We had seven programming assignments, a midterm, and a final, which were each all take-home and had equal weighting at the time. Again, we were granted extensions when we asked for it (and even then, the homework wasn't too intensive). I will note that I speak from the perspective of having had a small amount of programming experience in Java prior to taking the course.

reviews.content:
I expected the class to be pretty simple because I’ve taken Python before and I’m an intended CS major. I learned too late that you could skip out of the class, so I used it as a refresher since I hadn’t coded in Python in a couple of years.

Bauer's teaching style is great. He shares his screen to show his code and works through notes in Jupyter Notebook (posted after class), which is super clear. Don’t be afraid to ask questions or participate in class, he's really receptive and willing to explain logic multiple times or in different ways until you understand.

The content is fine overall. If you’ve never coded before, it might feel like a lot to learn in one semester, but if you take the course somewhat seriously, you’ll have a solid understanding of Python and computer science basics.

For those who’ve programmed or learned Python before, this course is pretty easy. If you want to get ahead, you can skip it (I didn’t because I already had credits for intro Java and didn’t know I could skip until the last minute). But it’s good for a review of Python or starting off with an easier course if that’s what you’re looking for.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
4 exercise sets, 5% each, all pass/fail (based on completion)

3 group projects, 8% each, not very long

3 exams, 18% each

Grading was fine overall. Exercise sets were essentially a guaranteed 20% of your grade as long as you attempted and submitted them, and video + code solutions from the TA's were posted. The group projects were manageable, and you could get away with waiting until the last day or two to start if someone in your group had coding experience (they try to balance groups to include at least one experienced coder). Had to meet with a TA to explain your code, but you aren't being quizzed on specifics, so I wouldn't worry too much about it.

For exams, we were given a clear list of topics to know and also specified what wouldn’t be tested. He also emphasized that reviewing the exercise sets was important for exam prep. Exam grading was fair (ex you could get partial credit on questions if you showed your work or logic).

The first two exams were fine, but the final one was more challenging. Even if you did well on the earlier exams, I’d recommend putting extra effort into studying for the final.

The only downside was that grading often took longer than expected. For example, grades that he promised to released in two days sometimes took over a week. Grades came out pretty slowly (even the pass/fail exercise sets), which was a little inconvenient but not a huge issue.

exercise sets: 1-2 hrs every 2 weeks
group projects: ~8 hours total for the first project (adjusting to group work style, felt less structured than the other two), 3–5 hours each for the other two
more time for exam prep, but much less than I would spend for other classes
I would say this class isn't as time-consuming as others, but make sure to acc prep for exams

reviews.content: As someone who came into this class with a lot of experience with Python, I didn't expect it to be challenging. Still, I can admire how well put together the progression of this course is and how well he teaches it. Prof. Bauer is very organized and his lecture notes are really good. Sometimes his lectures can be boring, especially if you already know Python pretty well.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Pretty light compared to other classes. Individual exercise sets are not bad, group projects are manageable, tests are very fair. He publishes all the content that may be on the test beforehand. Take this class with him.

reviews.content: Bauer is a really nice professor, explains things well in lecture, and is helpful during OH. Lectures can be slightly boring especially if you already know Python, but Bauer is a really nice guy and he definitely wants students to succeed because he tries to hint at topics that will be on tests. One thing to note about Python is that there is a group project aspect of this class. Get. A. Good. Group. There’s one chance to switch groups after the first group project is due, but getting a good one in the first place is just better.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Not a big time commitment. 4 exercise sets graded on completion worth 20% of your grade. 3 group projects worth 24% of your grade. You have to present your project to a TA after you submit to make sure that everyone in the group contributed and knows what is going on (this is why it is important to get a good group!!!). Basically, you have to tell them how all the functions work and such. 3 exams worth 54% of your grade. There isn’t a final. Instead, the 3rd exam is on the last day of class before the reading period. Exercise set 0 which is just setting up the software is 2% of your grade.

reviews.content:
Recently, I had the nightmare of taking "Intro to Python" by Timothy Paine. I can't believe I wasted an entire semester's worth of time on such a disaster of a course, and it is beyond me how anyone could teach a course and call it “education”. 

Going into this course, I thought that it would be an easy A. Past reviews of this course had said the same thing, except for one little detail: that Paine was NOT the professor. Paine’s organizational skills and lectures are all over the place. One minute, you’re learning about basic syntax, and the next you’re asked to create an AI program to detect and predict future medical diagnostics. It’s like Paine threw together random topics and created his syllabus by asking ChatGPT “What should I teach in a Python course?”. Spoiler alert: it’s a complete disaster.

About Paine himself: this person is the perfect example of boring and clueless. His teaching style is so dull and lifeless — it feels like he’s trying to put the entire class to sleep. There’s no passion, no engagement, nothing. It’s like he actully couldn’t care less about actually teaching the class. I find more excitement in cleaning my room than attending his lectures. No wonder less than 10 people in a 300 person lecture show up to class…

At the beginning of the course, no grading details were posted on the syllabus. The same thing for the middle and at the end of the semester. Despite consistent questions if Paine could post a grading scheme on Ed Discussion, there’s no response as Paine ghosts the entire class. And, as if things couldn’t get any better, Paine releases the final grades ONLY THREE WEEKS after the grade submission due date. 

You would think that the course wouldn’t be graded so harshly. It’s only an INTRODUCTORY class for FRESHMAN, so shouldn’t the class at least be taught well? Wouldn’t you expect Timothy Paine, a CS graduate from Columbia with SUMMA CUM LAUDE, to teach decently? And Paine says he can tutor CS for 300 DOLLARS PER HOUR on his website? You usually want someone with such accomplishments and connections to Columbia to teach a course you’re taking — unfortunately, I think my dog could teach this course just as well as Paine. Rather than getting a Master’s in Columbia’s CS, a degree from the Teacher’s College might be better suited for him. 

To be honest, this is probably the worst learning experience I’ve ever had. Please do yourself a favor and avoid this professor like COVID.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
7 HW assignments, 2 midterms, 1 final

Grades are DEFLATED:
- 95-100 = A
- 94-95 = A-
- 93-94 = B+

reviews.content: I took this class because it started off so easily. I love Jan, he is such a kind soul and so patient and really helpful. He’s a great teacher and can easily break down concepts and make it more digestible. His office hours are where he really shines. He is a bit too soft spoken and at times not a very dynamic lecturer like Blaer for example. But he can out teach Jae, and Blaer.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: I didn’t spend that much time, I didn’t even go to class too often because he had a zoom option and his notes were always great.

reviews.content: This course is not introductory at all. Bauer is good professor and cares about his student but my positivity ends here. His lectures are boring and explain very complicated thing. All of the students in this class are smart and know how to code python since freshman year of high school. If you don't know how to code initially like me, then you are in serious trouble. The lecture goes by very fast. Individual assignments are close to data structures in python, and are very hard. Quizzes are comparatively easier but still it's a lot of work and the worst thing is the upper quartile out of 40% is always 38 % because you have smart people taking the class for easy A when they could've taken Data Structures. You will always run for help and it is draining. The lectures are long and boring that half of the students don't even show up. The grading is not that terrible but TA's are always tired and take off marks because they don't even care to look at your assignments specifically. This class tested my patience. This class should be renamed as Data structures in python.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Not that bad.

reviews.content: If you have any prior programming experience at all skip this class. The entire course content could be learned in max one weekend. Stopped attending lecture after the 2nd or 3rd class - they're incredibly dry and focus on random minute details. Projects are generally easy and the quizzes are okay. As for the prof. - he seems nice enough in class but he's not really a nice person if you talk to him outside of lecture (YMMV). Overall I took this course to add Python to my skillset as a CS major but this class is really directed towards those with literally no programming experience at all. You also won't really learn much Python either as he spends a LOT of time going over pretty arbritrary aspects of Python (like 90% of the course is just formatting stuff).

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content:
I had no background in computer science whatsoever, and I found this course pretty difficult. I liked Professor Bauer, but I feel like because many students in the class were already familiar with a lot of the material, he moved too quickly. 
Each project took many hours, and I did not know how to do parts of them, despite attending every class. I also got points taken off for things that were not specified on the assignment descriptions but were apparently programming conventions(?) that I was not aware of. Just because your code does exactly what it's supposed to do does not mean you will get full credit.
The grade cut-offs were generous, though, and I ended up doing alright. I think you only needed like an 80% for a B+ and like 65 for a B. 
It's not a bad class, but it wasn't as easy as I expected based on other reviews. So just be aware of that if that'll also be the first computer science class for you!

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content:
This guy is a really bad teacher on two levels. First, his communication skills are lacking and it is unclear why he says the things that he does. And if you ask questions, he becomes irritated and implies that your question is stupid. Which leads me into point number two: I'm not sure why Professor Paine is teaching undergrads if his attitude is so horrible. You would think that he is God's gift to humanity, based upon his ego and dismissal of any semblance of intellectual curiosity. 
Stay far away. I got an A in his class, but it was the hardest A of my life because I had to learn from someone who clearly did not want or care to teach well. You're better off taking the class with a real professor that you can actually get to know and get advice from. The only saving grace of this class is that you grow closer to your classmates, because it is a hell of a journey -- and not in the good way.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content:
Bauer is a sweetheart, and a fantastic teacher. His wholesome smiling face absolutely made my Tuesdays and Thursdays. 1006 is a great first programming course - I had no prior experience and found it doable, and actually pretty fun.

His lectures were always dynamic, class materials were easy to understand, and homework problems were very chill. The quizzes are pretty tough, but it ends up balancing out (and the curve is nice).

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content: Professor Bauer is the best professor I've ever had!! I went into the class having no prior experience in Python, but he explained things extremely well and I now know how to code "mini-games" if you can call it that. I know many people say his lectures were dry, but I felt the opposite (for the most part). He even showed us a website filled with pictures of CATS following the Fibonacci sequence to add some spice to the class. The TAs for the most part were also really helpful and readily available to answer questions even outside of their OH. I learned a lot from prof Bauer and I would recommend this class to anyone who is looking to dip their toes in comp sci especially since there's no requirement to read the textbook in this class!! The workload is not too much. 4 individual projects and 4 group projects. There are also 2 quizzes and a final. I found the quizzes/exams to be quite hard and failed the first one because I'm a very slow test-taker, but Professor Bauer went over each question I got wrong during a private Zoom session and was super patient with me. Anyway, take this class if you are thinking about it!! It's great :)

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.content:
If only Tim Paine could teach. Two weeks into the course, we spent half a lecture asking questions about HOW homework works. Nope, not the codes we have to write nor the content we are supposed to learn in class, but simply HOW to submit homework. After that class, someone posted a question about homework on Piazza, and Tim basically called him out for "not going to class", though as someone who went to class I had the same question. 

Professor Paine is more than disappointing. His barely teaches and doesn't have a clear syllabus at all about what content we are supposed to cover. Going to lecture makes me more confused than not. For homework assignments, we lose points not by wrong or incomplete answers, but for stylistic headers he briefly mentioned in class but never clarified on the homework assignment itself. Basically, he takes points off for things we didn't even know we had to do.

I won't even make it to the midterms because I will be dropping this course for my sanity.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Approximately one problem set per week, but that again changes because people are so confused all the time and had to span Piazza two dozen times a day just to understand what is going on.

reviews.content: Bauer is a great professor. I had no programming experience before coming to Columbia, and taking 1006 with Bauer has made me strongly consider a major in CS. He is approachable, kind, and fair, and he really does care for the well-being of his students. While his lectures can be dry at times, his notes concisely lay out everything you need to know. I thought the quizzes and the final exam had some minor tricks, but they’re probably super easy if you have prior programming knowledge. The TAs are some of the best I’ve had in any of my classes - they’re patient and more than happy to steer you in the right direction without giving away too much. The head TA Spencer was always on top of hosting review sessions and preparing slides/Kahoots, which I found to be incredibly useful. As a whole, if you have to take 1006 (either because you’re in SEAS or because you want a gentler start to CS before taking 1004), I strongly recommend taking it with Bauer. He’s currently on parental leave this semester, but I hope to take more classes with him in the future!

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
5 In-Class Sets (20%) - Not too bad for the most part, and you can do them in groups of 2 or 3.
4 Take-Home Projects (25%) - There were originally 5, but the last one about machine learning became optional due to time constraints.
2 Quizzes (20%)
1 Final Exam (30%)
Attendance & Participation (5%)

reviews.content:
I honestly have the world of respect for Professor Ferguson. 

There were times in the semester that I was complaining a lot about this class. As someone who had never taken programming or computer science before, I walked in and I was immediately extremely confused. I went to the lectures, but I felt like they might as well be in French. 

However, Professor Ferguson realized that there was something wrong with this class. He asked for a lot of our feedback and drastically restructured how he taught later in the semester. Now, don't get me wrong, it wasn't perfect. But the fact of the matter is that he went through a world of effort to make the class better for his students. 

There was also some confusion pertaining to assignments, but I think that will be refined over time. Also, his office hours were incredibly helpful. He would make extra office hours in the weekend to help students. Again, with zero programming experience, this was key for my success in this class. 

The extra credit opportunities were also really helpful. 

Sure, he has his sassy moments, but I think he has a lot of respect for his students and a high commitment to the class.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: like 6 projects, extra credit

reviews.content: Professor Ferguson is the kindest professor I have ever had at Columbia.  He is on a mission to singlehandedly take stress culture out of the computer science department.  Take his classes.  Go to his office hours.  Be his friend.  He will be there for you, and his first concern is always your well-being.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Pretty intense.  He will help you with it all, and grant every extension you ask for.

reviews.content: Prof Bauer is a very kind and helpful man, who gives extremely dry lectures and unnecessarily difficult homework. Most of the time I did not even bother to go to his class. He uploads every lecture note, so that was helpful. He is really boring and it was really hard to concentrate in class but if you actually go to his office hours, you will see that he is very patient and will try to help you as much as he can.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: 5 homework, 1 midterm, 1 final

reviews.content:
Disclaimer: I went to two classes total.

I can't speak to his teaching style, but Dr. Bauer organized and designed the class very well. The coding exercises on the homework were generally simple and easy. For the programs that required a little more thought, Bauer provided skeleton code that tended to trivialize the problem. The midterms and final were fair. The tests both consisted of 
A few true/false that required you to know some small nuances of the python language. A few short answer about interpreting code.
1-3 simple coding exercise that required only basic control structures. 

Honestly,if you don't need this course as a requirement, you should just teach yourself the material. Otherwise, it's still a solid class to leisurely learn the bare basics of python. 

Also, his lecture notes contain everything you need to know.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: 1-3 hours a week. Going to class is VERY optional

reviews.content:
Adam Cannon is not a good profesor for this class. He is undeniably good for the Intro to Java, but my experience in Python is negative. He knows his stuff, and while excuses have to be made since this is only the 3rd year this course exists, he is still refining the curiculum. However, while the cotent of the lectures was interesting (read: sometimes, other times not falling asleep was hard) they were only vaguely related to the homework, and most of the time, were it not for online documentation on Python, me and all my friends in the class would have failed. Although he leaves time in lecture for questions, his sometimes sarcastic answers and interactions with students discourage many from asking. Oftentimes, he will not actually answer the question posed in class, just tells you to "deal with it" in a roundabout way, or gives a non-sensical answer. His office hours dont help: although he holds the same amount of office hours as other professors, he is teaching about 400 students at a time, so there is always at least a 10-20 student line waiting to talk to him during office hours. To be fair though, there are about 5 TAs, though they often are not clear on the specific requirements of the assignment and will sometimes give you wrong information if you ask a mildly specific/complex question on the problem sets. Desperate emails sent the day before the homework is due dont get answered until after the dealine (though to be fair, he warned us that he would take minumum 1 or 2 days to respond due to the impressive amount of emails he gets). 

Overall, although Cannon is a good teacher, he is not good for this course. The learning curve is very slow for the first 3 weeks, and gets incredibly hard after that. While about half the students in the class have programmed before, for the half who have not, the problema set take significantly more hours tan the 8-12 Cannon gives as reference. So start early. DO NOT LEAVE IT UNTIL THE DAY BEFORE OR YOU WILL NOT FINISH. 

Avoid this class unless you actually have to take it or you are pursuing a mayor/minor/concentration/ect in computer science or related fields. Takes up more time tan what is justified for a class that does not related or is not required for your degree (it is ridiculous how much time it takes away from studying for those clases which actually count towards your degree)!).

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
35% - biweekly problem sets, usually 12-15hr if no experience (sometimes he will split it into phase 1 due after 1 week and pahse 2 due in 2 weeks to make sure students do not leave it until the last minute)
25% - midterm, multiple choice, relatively easy after doing the problem sets
40% - final

reviews.content:
First off, there are 2 types of people that take this class: those who have programmed before, and those who have never programmed before in their life.  If you fall into the latter group, like myself, I HIGHLY recommend reading up a bit on Python before you take the class because the learning curve is steep.  This review will come from the perspective of someone with no former programming experience:

Intro to Comp Sci for Eng/App Sci is still in its 3rd year of infancy, so Adam Cannon is still developing the curriculum for this class.  Adam Cannon is a really nice guy who often makes the types of sardonic jokes that provoke a chuckle or two, verbally assumes that his class hates him, and gives riddles at the beginning of class to those students who already know the material and can afford to spend the duration of class pondering the riddle, life itself, or if they should attend the next class.  Lectures consisted of him going through topics rather rapidly (for someone who knows nothing of Python) and explaining examples of programs posted in CourseWorks.  For people with programming experience, the feeling of rushing may not have been the case, but some topics he introduced--especially for the homework--could be quite challenging.  We did not have a textbook, which I think would have been helpful, but I believe he is getting one next semester.  Often in class, Professor Cannon would ask if there were any questions and be greeted by silence and blank stares, to which he would respond, "If 1 of you doesn't understand something, that means 10 more of you don't understand it either," sigh, and move on, so ASK QUESTIONS if you don't understand something.  Those afraid to ask questions will be extremely grateful that you did.

Homework consists of bi-weekly projects that can be very tricky, so try not to procrastinate on these because Professor Cannon will answer questions about/go over the homework in class sometimes.  That being said, he will not baby you and give you the answer, only try to lead you on a path to finding the right answer, both in class and in office hours.  The TAs are all awesome and extremely nice (even if they are all really busy), and I highly recommend going to their office hours.  Both the midterm and final are written and doable, but you should study for them, no matter what programming background you have.  Overall, although this can be a challenging class, Adam Cannon is a satisfactory teacher, but it is up to you--the student--to ask him for help if you need it.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
35% bi-weekly Homework projects - can be more time-consuming than they appear, so start early!
25% Midterm Exam - written
40% Final Exam - written

reviews.content: This is heavily based on which TA you have. Adam doesn't teach this. It's all undergraduate students who teach this seminar
reviews.workload: Show up and you'll pass.

reviews.content: One of the kindest cs professors I've ever had. He is super understanding and always does his best to help/emphasis the importance of data structures in job interviews. Tries his best to include problems that are similar to those in interviews(definitely appreciated!). Lectures are recorded which is is super helpful. If you having trouble just stop by his office hours, and he will help you work through it.
reviews.workload: two midterms, 8 homework problems(some type of coding assignment based of the data structure of that week), five quizzes(worth like 5 percent total) and one capstone project, that counts as a final(can not go to OH for this).

reviews.content: This was the least effective class I have taken at Columbia. The instruction lacked precision, quality, and professionalism. Compared to Professor Jae’s clear and admirable teaching, this course did not meet the academic standards I expected from Columbia University.
reviews.workload: This course did not reflect Columbia’s usual academic standards. Columbia is generally an admirable institution that values multidisciplinary thinking and intellectual breadth. Professor Jae exemplifies these qualities and sets a strong example for teaching excellence.

reviews.content: I enjoyed Blaer's lectures, though they can be a little slow-paced. He's clear, thorough, and funny. Homework is a little tricky sometimes, just go to TA office hours when needed. Exams are easier than the homework in my opinion––they're largely straight-forward and Blaer literally walks through question-by-question what will be on the exam. Just pay attention and you'll be fine. Blaer sets a good foundation for an essential concept for computer science students.
reviews.workload: Homework took ~3-4 hours/week. Preparing for ~3-5 hours for an exam is fine.

reviews.content: I had heard good things about Blaer, and he fit most of the descriptions. He records his lectures which is great for reviewing more difficult concepts while studying. Pretty chill teacher and tells at least 1 joke or story a class. Direct and clear teaching style, explains concepts, gives examples, and then walks through it in code. The content was fine, more complex topics given in the later half so it's important to stay on top of things but overall not too difficult if you're willing to put in the work.
reviews.workload:
10 assignments (half written, half coding, given in pairs) with about 2 weeks to submit each pair. Assignments - 50%, midterm - 20%, final - 30%. 

The assignments are fair, they just may take a bit of time or extra thinking to complete. The exams I also thing are fair, you just need to seriously know the concepts and may have to memorize a bit of code for algorithms. He does a review session before the exam so you know what to study, and as long as you seriously follow it, you should be good.

reviews.content: Prof Blaer is great. His lectures are always interesting, and he sometimes sidetracks with somewhat related, funny stories. His lectures alternate between explaining the math behind an algorithm and implementing it in code. He tells you exactly what is expected of you, so as long as you pay attention and complete assignments, you will do fine. I took this class without having taken Intro Java, although I did take AP CSA in high school. He does warn against skipping Intro Java, but if you put in the work, it's completely manageable.
reviews.workload: 20% midterm, 30% final, 50% for 10 homework assignments. Half of the homeworks are written assignments, and half are coding. He gives about 2 weeks to complete each pair of assignments (one written, one code). He tells you exactly what will be on the exams, but he doesn't give practice exams.

reviews.content: Blaer is the goat. Had him for Intro to Java and Data Structures. His lectures are clear and easy to follow, and they're all recorded. I will say this course is pretty data structures theory focused, as in symbolic/pen-and-paper representations of the data structures, and not very focused on the coding aspect. This makes the class easier, but I wish we were given more opportunities to practice coding so the material would be actually useful.
reviews.workload: imo the midterm and final were easier the than the intro to java exams. The content was more straightforward, Blaer basically lays out what you need to know in a review sheet before the exams. 10 homeworks, assigned in pairs (1 written, 1 programming). One pair is dropped.

reviews.content: Blaer teaches very well and clearly. He wants every student to do well and this comes across. He is down to earth and does his best to make class interesting and entertaining through stories and jokes.
reviews.workload: 10 homework assignments (5 written, 5 coding), lowest two are dropped. The workload is very manageable. One midterm and final which are very fair (midterm average was 74.7%). He tells most of what are on the tests so they are easy to prepare for. His TAs are wonderful and are so helpful during office hours. The course is curved to a B+/A- average.

reviews.content:
Half of my lecture class didn't attend any lectures and didn't attend office hours as they probably needed - they are who are probably complaining about Professor Borowski. Or they never reviewed the lecture slides before/ahead of class. Or they chatgpt the homework assignments. 

This class is simple: Do the work necessary to succeed, and you will. The professor isn't playing any tricks (unlike some other professors you might find at Columbia).
reviews.workload: Workload is hard, but if you're taking any cs core class expecting a light workload, you're going to be in for a shock.

reviews.content: This is probably the most important class to get past any CS interview and your preparation for AP, so it's pretty important. Borowski does an OK job at guiding you through it–not great and not terrible. His explanations are especially not great. He really loses me when he starts reading off code. However, all lectures are recorded and you can rewatch them as many times as needed, which makes up for it. One thing I did like were the HackerRank problems we did, since I think it's useful to develop the intuition to recognize that those problems could be solved by very briefly modifying a data structure or an algorithm covered in class.
reviews.workload: The homeworks ranged from 2-4 hours (definitely on the higher side of that for the theory HWs, while the first two programming assignments were closer to 1). The capstone project was more similar to an AP lab at about 6 hours. The exception to this is the red-black tree assignment. Get started on that EARLY. Your worse midterm is graded as 10% of your grade, your better midterm is 15% (one of the midterms is the in-class final). The 8 programming HWs and 4 theory HWs are 45% total and the final capstone project is 25%. The remaining 5% are quizzes which are literally a free 10/10 (they are take home and you get 2 attempts). The first midterm was pretty long and a lot of the class did not finish, so the second midterm (final) was easier. Both had an average of low-to-mid 60s. Fortunately, they carry little weight, so the class is a pretty easy B+ or better if you know what you're doing.

reviews.content: Brian Borowski is a very kind professor who seems genuinely invested in the success of his students. He goes over the topics in depth with multiple examples to ensure that you have a good understanding of the material and always relates the content of the course to real world applications (especially as they relate to technical interviews). He always makes an effort to get to know his students so I would 100% recommend going to office hours if you need help. The content of this course can sometimes be difficult but if you study and pay attention to everything he says in lectures then you'll be fine.
reviews.workload: Multiple coding assignments/quizzes/written assignments, but the grading was mostly fair and the averages were usually very high. Be careful with how you submit though because the rubric is quite picky when it comes to that. My only criticism is that the assignments were very technical and gave you a good understanding of how a concept works, but not so much how to implement it in a real application.

reviews.content: Idk who hired this guy and why.
reviews.workload: The assignments are poorly constructed and take up too much time. Worst course plan ever.

reviews.content: Amazing professor! Super nice and friendly - he'll answer any question you have!
reviews.workload: A lot of work but necessary to learn

reviews.content: While Dr. Borowski may be seen as strict in his grading, it will definitely prepare you for more advanced programming classes, such as Advanced Programming. He goes over both conceptual and programming skills very well and is overall a nice guy. His TA's were great as well and his organization made help very accessible.
reviews.workload: Grading was fair, feedback was provided. He will say this at the beginning of the class but remember to have all outputs correct (i.e spacing, capitalization, etc) and files submitted as requested! Spent 1-2 hours on most assignments, going upwards to 4 on the harder ones. Two in class midterms, weekly assignments (theoretical or programming), occasional online quizzes, and a final project.

reviews.content: I feel like a lot of people don't like Professor Borowski but I thought he was perfectly fine and I really enjoyed this class. He was good at explaining things and since he was new he actively welcomed feedback about how to make the class better / be a better teacher. Also his office hours are very helpful. I recommend taking this class in your freshman year so you are prepared for the internship recruiting cycle in August.
reviews.workload: It's a hard class but worth it!

reviews.content:
I expected to learn a lot about Data Structures, and I admit that I know now a lot more than I did at the beginning of the semester, but that was mainly because I worked extremely hard on my own and went to many office hours to understand the content and do the assignments rather than take a lot from Dr. Borowski's lectures. Professor Borowski is not a great lecturer.

He is not excellent at explaining things in class, and he struggles to gain the attention of all the students because he mostly reads from the slides and does not give any explanations that may add to the content in any way.

The problem is that Dr. B and the TAs may not be very helpful.

Once in his office hours, Dr. B struggled with helping a student debug their code. Similarly, once a TA gave us a problem that he had originally said would take us 15 minutes to solve, and when he did that same problem during recitation, it took him 1 hour and 20 minutes to do the same. Also the class size is very large, so we had to wait hours for debug a single problem out of nine problems on each assignment.

However, Dr. B didn't effectively convey the content. A good number of his assignments are focused on coding the basic implementations of the methods for Data Structures, such as binary search trees, AVL trees, and hash maps. In my opinion, this is not a good thing because he did not give us enough practice using the method implementations to code more complex methods. This problem with the assignments is especially bad when you are practicing for coding interviews.
reviews.workload:
Workload:
12 assignments (45%, lowest grade dropped)
A Capstone Project (25%)
Quizzes (5%, lowest grade dropped)
Two Midterm Exams (lowest grade 10%, higher grade 15%)


Dr. B's workload is awful. He gives many assignments. His first Midterm Exam was in October, and his second Midterm Exam was on the last day of classes. Then, after the second Midterm, you had one week to complete a Capstone Project during the other final exams. That is a lot!
 
He often deducts marks for silly things, such as using additional space in the answers.
 
Dr. B gave 9 late days throughout the semester for 12 assignments in total. You cannot use late days on the Capstone Project and two of the theoretical assignments. Dr. B is not lenient with providing extensions. He provided class-wide extensions on two of the assignments, which led to work management issues as deadlines for them were pushed to be one or two days before the midterms.
 
Additionally, I have heard of a student who spent the whole week working on the Capstone project, and as a result, she did not have enough time to study for her final exams. She made a mistake in her submission, which was that she submitted an entire file instead of the specified code snippet, so Dr. B did not accept her work and gave her a 0. Her class grade went down to a C-. Each week, I spent around ten to fifteen hours on the assignments for this class, and if I had an exam or a quiz, I would spend even more time studying.

reviews.content: Very kind and helpful professor. Despite the large class size, he tries his best to assist every student.
reviews.workload: Heavy but fair workload. 5-10 hours per week.

reviews.content: Dr. B is an excellent professor. While I had some knowledge of data structures going into the course, meaning that I can't comment as someone learning the material totally for the first time, I believe he did a good explaining concepts and was very open to answering questions. He or his TAs also responded promptly to every question on EdStem, which was very helpful because there was less pressure on understanding everything just during class time. Dr. B is polite, funny, and very knowledgeable about his course. It's clear he cares about his students and their learning.
reviews.workload: As someone who went into the course with some familiarity with the material, I did not think the assignments were super difficult, but I can see how they could be more challenging for others. That being said, the median grades are quite high, and you almost always have a week to complete them, so you have time to be confused, ask questions, and figure things out. Grading could be strict, with lots of extra test cases, but it was always fair and logical.

reviews.content: Before getting into this class, other CS majors said that DS would be easy. For me, it was a little harder than Intro to Java with Blaer. There is a lot of more content to understand and fit in. Blaer does a good job of going through and explaining the overall general concepts of DS but I found him to digress into off topic subjects this semester, which made the learning tougher for me. I did not enjoy how he taught us how to code using DS algorithms by just perusing through the textbook code. It would have been nice if had done live coding of DS algorithms in example coding like he did in Intro to Java, because when it came to completing the homeworks, I understood the concepts but barely know how to code such concepts from scratch. His grading policy is very consistent, which I appreciate. The midterm was more difficult than what I expected. Even though he said what was going to be on the midterm, I found the questions to be more complex than I thought. There were a lot of tree questions, even though he had taught it the week prior without giving us time to absorb how trees work through homework. I like the class' consistency in written and coding assignments.
reviews.workload: 5 written and 5 coding assignments (50%), midterm (20%), final (30%)

reviews.content: I had Blaer for intro java as well and really enjoyed his teaching, which is why I wanted him for data structures. I loved how all the classes were recorded because it was really easy to catch up on missed material and review for tests. Also, his grading policy was very lenient. His mean tends to be a B+ and his median an A-. There are 8-10 homework assignments (half written, half coding), one midterm, and a final. You get two weeks to complete each homework assignment, and 8 late days.
reviews.workload: I probably spent 5-10 hours on each coding assignment and under 5 hours per written assignment.

reviews.content: Borowski's course load was fair. Data structures is not an easy topic and the class was challenging at times, but Borowski always listened to input and was flexible. Also, he tries his best to be engaging and teach difficult topics with simple explanations. Much of the class received an A or A-, so accusations of poor grading are really unfounded (the curve was not harsh at all). Finally, Borowski is very approachable in general (many people would stop and ask him questions after class, while he genuinely tried to explain/help however he could). Just make sure to know Java before you start, put in the work, and you'll be fine.
reviews.workload: Weekly assignments that can take 4-8 hours (10 max). 2 midterms (1 is dropped), 1 final project (which was not much more intricate than the weekly assignments)

reviews.content: Very sweet guy, tries to be funny and entertaining to keep the mood light in class, very intelligent man btu course is def catered towards peopel with [revious data structures experience. Can be very hard to keep up in class without feeling overwhelmed so most of my learning was done by rewatching lectures and pausing to take notes slowly. Programming projects were challenging but definitly doable, especially with the help of TAs, midterms were difficult but also most of the content tested was expected, only a few questions felt out of the blue. Offered extra credit assignments to help students. Would disagree when people say he was too stubborn and isn't open to feedback because he actively asked for feedback at many benchmark times in the course and also shifted things like hw deadlines, midterm grade boost opportunities, extra credit, etc to try and accommodate the biggest things students were asking for. He can't change everything for us and for students to expect that is unreasonable. Overall decent expereince, very challenging for me but I learned a lot and did good work.
reviews.workload: Pretty heavy workload, weekly programming project/theoretical written assignment, 2 midterms, 1 final project

reviews.content: He's a good professor. For context, this is the only class in Java I've taken at Columbia, so I wouldn't be able to compare it to other professors, but he was good. I found coding assignments to be easier than the theoretical ones. Grading  is fair, similar standards to other computer science classes. He's approachable and good at explaining. I did most of my lectures over zoom and it was sufficient to get a good grade. Midterms are time constrained.
reviews.workload:
Weekly assignments
2 Midterms, drops lowest
1 Final project

reviews.content:
1. Unreasonable deadlines
There were assignments due every week, no late hours. He said this is fair because 'the hw with the lowest grade is dropped'.. LMAO. Wouldnt advice on taking this class with other heavy courses (especially if you're new to programming) because this prof acts like his class is the only one his students are taking

2. Really disorganized
People often say the best way to complete assignments on time is by 'starting early'. Well meet this class, where its almost impossible to start early because the coding assignments will be updated as late as one day before its due.

3. 'Industry'
The prof will keep on saying that his unreasonable deadlines and his hackerranks 'teach you what its like in the industry' lol. If you know anything about current coding intrerviews at top companies, you'll understand how out of reach this approach is
reviews.workload: Expect to be spending between 20 - 40 hours per week doing his assignments, especially if you're new to programming. Might take significantly less hours if you already understand data structures and have strong programming fundamentals

reviews.content: Actually liked the content, found it very useful and logical, hated the professor
reviews.workload: Workload was huge at the beginning of the semester, the professor did not know how to run a Columbia CS classes, he gave no late hours, was very stubborn, he assigned way too much homework that literally could not be done alone, each week the programming project took at least 20h if not more, the nice thing was that he provided test cases for most assignments (so you knew how you would probably do on the assignment, however I found it stress inducing because you were spending so much time getting all the test cases to work), the TA office hours were always super crazy (since nobody could do the assignment alone), I think he did not guess the time commitment for each assignment correctly, this class almost made me burn out, then there was also a mess with the grading, basically he replaced the final with a second midterm on the last day of classes (so basically a final) AND a final project which I know will take forever, he is so stubborn and not open to any feedback, I hate this class even though I enjoyed the material, he would also make you do Hackerranks in class which I found to take up too much time and was not helpful in learning the material, he also did not release solutions to HWs which was frustrating because sometimes you did not know what you did wrong

reviews.content: I didn't know Hagrid's calendar moves at a different rate than us mortals. When Hagrid says he will upload homework or post your grades at a certain time, expect that to take maybe about ten times longer because us mortals' calendars somehow move at a faster speed than Hagrid's.

The review dated June 09, 2020 is probably the most accurate review of this class imo. In short: Blaer is a lovely, hilarious teddy bear that I want to befriend irl but he isn't the most outstanding Professor.
I think that Blaer can choose better TAs tbh. There are several TAs who are frequently arriving to their OHs late/ forgetting to attend their own OHs. Furthermore, some of them don't bother to refresh their memory on the current topics/homework. That being said, Bo is the most amazing TA I've ever met! He taught me to approach Blaer's data structures class in a more lighthearted manner. I will miss Bo after this semester!

The review dated June 09, 2020 is probably the most accurate review of this class imo. In short: Blaer is a lovely, hilarious teddy bear that I want to befriend irl but he isn't the most outstanding Professor.
I think that Blaer can choose better TAs tbh. There are several TAs who are frequently arriving to their OHs late/ forgetting to attend their own OHs. Furthermore, some of them don't bother to refresh their memory on the current topics/homework. That being said, Bo is the most amazing TA I've ever met! He taught me to approach Blaer's data structures class in a more lighthearted manner. I will miss Bo after this semester!

The class content is not hard. Professor Paul tends to extend the homework due date when most students starting on it later than his expectation. That's great since we were supposed to have 6 homework sets and now we have 5.
The entire TAing system is a mess. When there are questions regarding clarification of the homework problems, TAs may give inconsistent answers. So the best thing to do is post the clarification question on Piazza directly.
Homework problems are related to his lecture closely. And he sometimes will talk through the structure of some coding homework problems during class which is helpful.
Exams are similar to homework but much easier.

This class is a hot mess. I don’t know if it is because it’s online or just his teaching style but the lectures are super confusing. It seems that he just talks and talks and expects the information to naturally stick. Even worse, the textbook makes no sense and is very dense. Being the only DS class offered this semester I had to take it, but definitely one of the most confusing classes I have taken so far.

Prof. Blaer is my favorite professor at Columbia and I loved taking Data Structures with him! His lectures always target the key points, and he’ll occasionally throw in a relevant joke or story. He’s also accommodating and receptive to feedback, and the curve is generous. Even if you aren’t pursuing a CS degree, I highly recommend taking Data Structures with him if you enjoyed 1004.
My only complaint is that the Weiss textbook is subpar and should not be your primary resource in this class. The book is dense and reads more like an academic paper; it’s clogged with esoteric proofs and errors. Use Weiss for its source code, but refer to Cracking the Coding Interview, YouTube videos (I recommend the Back To Back SWE channel), and sites like GeeksforGeeks for mastering the concepts.

The good: Blaer is nice, funny, approachable, and the curve is generous. The hw sets are also reasonable.

The bad: Blaer is not a good lecturer. The currciuculum glosses over a lot of topics. The motivation behind the data structures are not explained. Honestly, data structures at Columbia is a joke. For a class that is very important to computer science, you will feel like you can do the problem sets and maybe get As, but will end the class thinking that you did not learn anything. Connections between the data structures are not explained. A lot of times I had knowledge of the topic behind explained, but sat there and saw him explain it for the first time and thought that if this was my first time being exposed to what he is saying, I wouldn't have grasped the material. Honestly, a very frustrating experience. Also the book is terrible; the code is filled with a lot bugs. Skip class and learn the material on your own. Also use problems sets from other universities to actually learn data structures. If you are doing the problem sets being assigned and think they are easy, that is because you are not learning actual data structures, just a bunch of disconnected programs. The theory part is better than the programming though. The course lacks the depth needed for cs.
reviews.workload: Reasonable.

reviews.content:
Hagrid is a clear, knowledgeable, kind, and helpful professor. I admit the class felt a little easy because of how slow he went; I ended up not paying attention to most lectures and instead relied on the very excellent textbook by Weiss to get me through. The homeworks and tests were quite easy and fair.

It's not a breeze though. You need to put in the time to understand these occasionally complex algorithms, and develop an intuition for them. If you know the basics of Java, the programming is a breeze. The written homeworks (i.e. exercises from the textbook) were occasionally difficult, but never completely stumped me. I never used them, but I've heard office hours and TAs are genuinely incredible.
reviews.workload:
One written and one programming homework every two weeks-ish
One midterm
One final

reviews.content:
Blaer is a nice guy who is not a great teacher. As a professor of a large lecture class, those two qualities are heightened: his jokes (though repetitive) can be stress-relieving, and if you have a background in java, his explanations are intriguing. However, if you don't have a background in java, Blaer is not very good at explaining simple concepts. He over-explains, confuses students, and gets distracted easily. I personally felt that my time was better spent on learning java online than learning in his class.

One specific moment that comes to mind is Blaer's introduction to stacks. He went on an hour-long description of the intricacies of a stack, over-explaining it, when in all honesty it's a somewhat-simple java topic. All he really needed to say was "this is like a list, but instead of being able to access any node at any time, stacks follow the process of last-in first-out, like a tissue box or a pile of books."

To be fair to Blaer, he is an incredibly nice professor who has the difficult job of teaching nearly 450 students in one large lecture class. I'm not sure anyone would have been able to do as good a job as online learning, especially in a class on Computer Science. 

My advice: take his class, but don't expect it to be great. Enjoy the comedic, positive side of Blaer, and deal with the negative sides of the class by learning online or reading the textbook.
reviews.workload:
- 6 written HWs (25%). + 6 programming HWs (25%) **He lets you drop your lowest written/programming hw grade
- Midterm (20%)
- Final (30%)

reviews.content: Extremely kind, fair, and helpful professor. I really enjoyed his class, and his grading is very fair. He’s super welcoming to questions and always stays after class to answer all the students’ questions. His lecture slides are very clear and super helpful for understanding how the different data structures and algorithms work. Great class!
reviews.workload: Very fair and manageable

reviews.content:
Bauer is an excellent professor. His lecture slides are probably the most useful thing; they're super clear and easy to understand. He breaks down the concepts through visual animations which is nice if you're a visual learner. I took intro to java with Paul Blaer, and I would say Blaer is definitely more engaging and makes the class fun. Whereas BAUER can be kind of dry and I've fallen asleep twice during lecture.
