Some, myself included, found her intimidating in class because she would sometimes answer student's questions with "I'm not sure where your getting confused" which can be awkward for the student asking the question but Tal doesn't mean it with an ill intention. So, if you can get over this bit you should be fine or go to her OH and ask in a smaller setting. 
I'm not sure how this course will be structured when we go back to campus but the format was three unit tests worth 30%, 30%, 10% of your final grade. I got somewhat below average on all of them - nothing by more than 5% less than average - but did fine on the homework (except for one where I got 50! lol) and the quizzes and ended up with a B+ so the curve is really generous. For context, the averages for the tests in fall 2020 were around 70% each time and I genuinely thought I had failed the second test which was worth 30% yike. 
With all that being said, I do think that the homework grading can be inconsistent and sometimes (rare for me at least though) just doesn't make sense. Grading is not always inconsistent, but it certainly feels shitty when something unfortunate like that happens to you. But, as long as you go to office hours when confused you should be able to get some helpful pointers about where to start - some TAs are more helpful than others so best to figure that out in the beginning of the term. 
This class was one of those courses where I disliked it during the course but reflecting on it, it wasn't so bad. That is a strong argument for not taking the course though...
TLDR: The curve will save you even if you feel like you are failing.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.content: I used to aim for A/A- for all of my classes, but I think I'm failing this course.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.content: The class is basically taught and graded entirely by the TAs who do not know how to grade. Grading was always late (2 of the 5 homework assignments were graded after the final exam) and feedback was terse. Omri doesn't seem to care about his students because he's too busy doing other things. Many times he wouldn't be in his office during his office hours. Take this class with other professors who will actually take their job seriously.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Easy homework, brutal exams (mind you, that's like 80% of your grade)

reviews.content:
The reviewer below clearly has not taken any advanced math class at Columbia. Omri's explanations of theoretical concepts is very good, and if you have any experience with proof based math courses, you will probably really enjoy his exposition. 

The reviewer is correct that lectures are the exact same as the textbook, but that doesnt mean that they are not worth going to; reading and understanding the textbook by yourself can take an extremely long time whereas Omri will streamline and highlight important parts of the proofs in class.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
Homeworks are straightforwards (can easily get 95+, but the averages were low)
Midterm was very easy 
Final was harder but pretty doable with a complete understanding of the material

reviews.content: Definitely not the best at explaining concepts, which is kind of critical considering that this course is very abstract and theoretical. It can also get very hard to take notes on his lecture because he often would not write down a complex idea he is talking about and/or scribble very few words about it. He does regurgitate the textbook almost verbatim, so you can totally get away with not attending class.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 1 problem set every roughly three weeks, which is reasonable. They can take a while to do, however, if you do not understand the material. Midterm was very straight forward and the class average was like 94%, but the final was atrocious. The average is not released at this time of writing but it is probably around 40%.

reviews.content: This is a strong class. Pretty straightforward, not such easy concepts but very clearly explained in the textbook. Chen is a really good and straightforward lecturer. I find that once in lecture and reading a concept once/twice in the textbook made my understanding strong. TA's super helpful too.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 5 homeworks, one is dropped. The homeworks take time, and they are taken from a previous course iteration so they are disproportionately hard. The exam is really easy.

reviews.content:
Aho is apparently retiring, so perhaps this review won't be useful anymore. However, he also tried to retire 2 years ago and is still here, so I'm not really sure what he is doing?

In general, I enjoyed the class. I thought the homeworks in particular were very well thought out – 5 problems, only 5 homeworks per semester and he drops the lowest grade. They neatly covered the concepts and they weren't easy, but they weren't too hard. With some help from office hours, I learned a lot from completing the homeworks, and got good grades on all of them. Aho's office hours are quite good, but the TAs helped a lot as well.

That being said, unfortunately I did feel like I learned a lot more from the homeworks than I did from the class. Aho is not a very engaging lecturer – he talks very slowly in a monotone voice. He also fails to go over very many examples for a lot of the theorems, because they are common sense to him (he is a very Smart Man). I do, however, believe that you can learn to learn from Aho – at the beginning of the semester I felt lost at every lecture, but towards the middle and end I realized that if I attended class and wrote down everything he said, then went over it later for ~30 minutes with the online lecture notes, I could definitely understand the material.

Note: apparently Aho is also the only one who teaches lambda calculus (other than Verma, who is new). Although the subject itself is easy, it is also useless plus it means the rest of the semester is rushed so that he can fit in lambda calculus.

Overall, I would say it is a good course taught by a good professor. However, it seems that the other sections have been taught by amazing professors (Yannakakis, Verma, etc.), so make sure you look at your options but don't feel bad if you get stuck with this one.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
5 homeworks (drop the lowest one) (15%)
1 midterm (40%)
1 "final" that is really just another midterm (45%)

reviews.content:
A well-executed class. Tal Malkin is very clear, puts a lot of effort into teaching, and knows that mathematical maturity among her audience varies wildly. Thus, she gives intuition as well as rigor, followed by many examples. She likes to get people to participate in lecture by answering or asking questions. This can be either illuminating or frustrating, depending on said people in class.

For the most part, lectures followed Sipser quite closely, although she merely sketched many of the more involved proofs, e.g. for PCP. The material was interesting enough, and she tries to give some motivation or application. However, the complexity portion of the class was much too rushed: we skipped many proofs and handwaved everything else.

Recitation notes were regularly posted, and these were quite long and poorly LaTeXed but very thorough, so I can't complain.

Most everybody who takes this class has to, so I recommend taking her iteration of it.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
9 homeworks, 1 dropped - 15%. Requires a little but not too much thought. Sometimes annoyingly tedious, especially in the beginning portion of the class where formal rather than high-level descriptions were required. The TAs seemed to grade reasonably, although once I had 5 points taken off a proof which was "lazy" (i.e. sneaky) and "didn't do what they were looking for", which seemed silly.

Midterm - 40%. Very easy, although the previous semester's (= our practice midterm) was a bit harder. 2 double-sided cheat sheets allowed.

Non-cumulative final - 45%. A bit harder, much more proofy. 2 double-sided cheat sheets allowed.

reviews.content:
Professor Yannakakis is a very capable lecturer. Although he has a soft voice and a slight accent, his explanations are very clear and so are his answers to questions. It's not a super exciting class, but at least you won't be confused. 

His problem sets are also reasonable and do not contain anything he hasn't taught. 

His exams are trickier, since they require not just walking through algorithms but also understanding concepts on a deeper level. Definitely read over the lecture notes very carefully.

Finally, he actually answers questions on Piazza!

Take Yannakakis if you get him.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
Problem Sets - 40% of the course grade, lowest one dropped. There were 6 problem sets, due every two weeks. Definitely doable.

Midterm - 25% of the course grade. Combination of walking through algorithms and true/false questions and free response.

Final - 35% of the course grade. Like the midterm, but slightly longer (although definitely not twice as long as the midterm).

reviews.content:
Fantastic professor. He was extremely clear throughout every lecture, and took time after every lecture to answer every question you have, even if that means reviewing what he went over in class. If you're taking CS courses in the summer, definitely consider this one to knock out your requirements.

The problem sets didn't take too long, and as for the midterm and final, he gives out a study guide that will indicate pretty much what *exactly* will be on them. The workload is very, very light, and the exams are very fair if you use the study guides he provides. Honestly, you can spend very little time preparing outside of class for the exams if you pay attention in class and sometimes stay after class to ask questions because he's that clear (some will say slow-paced, but the concepts are very well-elucidated). He largely covers the textbook, but I never found myself really needing to turn to it.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
-Weekly problem sets (should take at most 5 hours for each one)
-One midterm
-One final

reviews.content:
Prof. Malkin is the best. Not only does she understand and explain the material very thoroughly, she also makes a genuine effort to learn her students' names and engage the class. She has this one-liner which she uses when nobody raises their hand: 

"You either do not understand and should ask a question, or you understand and can give me the answer." - Prof Malkin's honesty/authenticity shows through in one-liners like this one. 

Lecturing style - probably one of the best lecturers in the department. She does this thing where she gives a hand-waving, intuitive explanation of something, and then shows it formally. 

She is extremely approachable and very open about how grading is done in the class. Prof. Malkin and her TAs put in an try very hard to make the course fair, always retroactively applying a policy change to all students if one student brings it up, and I think that this attitude starts at the top with Prof. Malkin setting the example.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: A written homework every week. Some of them are easier than others - the hardest ones might take you a few hours to do well.

reviews.content:
Very underwhelming class. I chose to take CS Theory with Aho due to his fame...in hindsight, this was a bad decision for me. I'm sure there are other people who feel differently, but this was my experience:

Lectures- Aho seems to think that the material is a lot easier than it actually is, often failing to adequately explain simpler concepts in favor of complex proofs, etc. that never appeared on homeworks or exams. This is probably due to the fact that he pretty much invented a lot of it; however, for most of us, this was our first experience with theoretical computer science.

Aho also just plainly isn't an engaging lecturer. Listening to him lecture is a lot like listening to your great-uncle drone on about the Great Buckwheat Shortage of '68 (if your great-uncle is a great storyteller, then ignore this). Occasionally, Aho will talk about having dinner with Stephen Wolfram or working with Kernighan and Ritchie at Bell Labs, which is always cool but doesn't necessarily make the class worth taking.

Homeworks- hard, but doable. There were five problems per problem set. They were problems that you had to do out and solve, which turned out to be useless because:

Exams- both the midterm and final were 10 true/false questions (with brief explanation). I just don't understand how ten true/false questions can adequately assess your knowledge of CS Theory. For the midterm, I studied all the algorithms and the workings of automata, but I did poorly on the exam (far below average). Many of the T/F questions were tricky (average was a 45, std. dev. of 22).

For the final, I didn't bother to learn how to solve any problems or do any proofs, because I knew they weren't going to be on the exam. Didn't really know much about Turing Machines. Bad mindset, I know, but I just studied the general concepts and did much better than the class average (which was a 75).

In conclusion- my recommendation? Take this class with someone else. I was not impressed...I'm not trying to be disrespectful towards Aho, but he is a professor that should be known for his accomplishments, not his teaching ability. Apparently he got a Great Teacher Award from Columbia at some point, but I feel like that has a lot to do with his legacy. I dunno, someone might come along and say something different, but I found the class dull and uninspirational.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
5 problem sets, drop 1: Hard but doable. Problems never showed up on exams.
Midterm: 10 true/false questions. Mean of 45, std. dev. of 22. Tricky questions.
Final: 10 true/false questions. Mean of 75, std. dev. unknown. Much easier than midterm.

Average weighted overall score was 67.3. Average letter grade was a B+.

reviews.content: Well organized notes, very straightforward exams - very similar to the practice questions she provides.  Probably one of the nicest professors on Columbia's campus.  Office hours incredibly helpful.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Bi-weekly homework assignments (~8 hrs each). Midterm, final exam.

reviews.content:
Computer science theory with Professor Yannakakis is a pretty good class; definitely one of the better classes Iâ€™ve taken in the computer science department.  There was nothing exceptional about it, but the fact that there was nothing strikingly wrong with it puts it well ahead of most other CS classes Iâ€™ve taken. 

The professor wrote excellent lecture notes which he posted online, and followed them closely during lectures.  He also handled questions from the class very well, and it was clear that no question ever came close to phasing him.  His progression through the material was both organized and logical.  If I had any criticism, it would be that we went rather slowly through details of proofs and constructions that didnâ€™t seem very fundamental to the course, and we couldâ€™ve gone through a bit more material if some of this was streamlined.  

The assignments for the course were very reasonable in scope and they did a good job enforcing the important points for each topic.  It seemed that he actually chose the problems based on what he covered in lecture and thought was important.  They were assigned and due every 2 weeks, and each consisted of four problems of varying difficulty.  Solutions to these were posted after they were handed in, and graded problem sets were returned a week after completion.

The exam were also pretty fair.  Some problems were more difficult than others, but nothing too ridiculous.  Both exams were during the 75 minute class period, so the scope of the problems was not very large.  The median on the midterm was 73 and the median on the final was 63.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
40% Problem Sets, of which there were 6
30% Midterm - median 73 standard derivation 15
30% Final - median 63 standard derivation 15

reviews.content:
This was an OK class. CS Theory with Yannakakis is neither good nor bad. The subject itself is very interesting. It's just the presentation of the material by Yannakakis and the textbook (HMU) that is lacking.

Yannakakis is no doubt a brilliant man, but he's a mediocre teacher. He puts up slides of lecture notes on Courseworks and teaches directly off of them in class. This led to maybe 30 out of 87 students actually attending the class.

The textbook often has convoluted proofs and too few examples. It's the defacto textbook for automate theory, but I think it could be improved. Sipser is another book which has slightly better explanations.

Yannakakis teaches concepts in a reasonable manner given the dense material. Most people didn't attend class and just studied from the slides and textbook. His explanations are not much better than the textbook and you can learn everything from his slides.

My advice is to make sure you are up to speed with what's being covered in class. The material can be dense and hard to follow, so try not to get lost because it will lead to a disaster when exams come around.

Problem sets (40% of grade) generally have 1 or 2 easy questions and the rest are hard. It is advisable to check your work with classmates since homework counts for 40% of your grade and you shouldn't lose too many points on it.

Don't worry too much if you don't completely understand some complicated proofs (eg- NFA to Regex, PDA to CFG conversions). If you know the method that it proves, you'll be fine for exams. He never asked to prove something in an exam. Questions were along the lines of design a DFA, CFG, Turing machine, algorithm, do a reduction, etc. Some of them can be tricky.

The midterm (30%) and final (30%) consisted of 6 and 5 questions respectively and were both in class. They were manageable, but kind of hard since we got so little practice solving problems. The course is mostly theory with few examples and 4 problems per homework don't really prepare you for the tests. Make sure to study all the lecture slides and problem sets for exams. Read the textbook whenever you get confused by the lecture slides.

Grading is fair. TAs grade both problem sets and exams. Final letter grades were also very reasonable.

I wouldn't avoid Yannakakis, but neither would I recommend taking this class if someone better (like Aho or Malkin) were teaching it the next semester.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
6 problem sets (4-5 questions + 3 online questions via Gradiance) (lowest dropped)
1 midterm (medium - hard)
1 final (hard)

reviews.content:
CS Theory as taught by Yannakakis is a good class -- it achieves everything you basically expect a class to, though it isn't outstanding in any particular regard. 

For almost the entire semester Yannakakis follows the textbook ("Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation"), and it pays to read the text ahead of time. The book is light on theory and heavy on examples, and you could probably get away with not going to class for the first 10 weeks or so until Turing Machine reductions start to be explained, because the book's explanations until then are always thorough enough. Lecture clarifies and sometimes expands a bit on the book, but not in any fundamental way, e.g. there might be a slower and a faster way to implement a given algorithm, and the book gives the slower one while Yannakakis will show the faster one in class. Once you get into Turing Machines, going to lecture is pretty important. The book sucks on reductions.

As a lecturer Yannakakis isn't exciting (it didn't help that this semester's room was poorly lit and had amphitheater style seating -- quite conducive to dozing off) but he is usually quite effective at going through examples clearly. He's been doing this for long enough to know which points people get confused about, and he makes sure to hammer those home. The only times I was truly lost in class were on a handful of particularly weird proofs that he demonstrated purely to make a point; they never came up on homework or exams.

Yannakakis is (as those of you who've Googled him will know), a pretty big name in the field with a prize or two to his name. There aren't many opportunities in CS Theory for him to show off his brilliance, but he is clearly in total command of the material in a way that not all professors always are. He virtually never makes mistakes on the blackboard (he's usually working from his lecture slides, which are excellent and available on CourseWorks), and will occasionally respond to a seemingly narrow question by tying it to much broader questions and answering those, too.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
1 midterm, 1 final, 30% each. 6 homeworks, 40%, partly written, partly through an online service called Gradiance. The grading was usually pretty fair. One TA graded all problem 1's, a different one graded all problem 2's, etc.

The midterm and final are both pretty manageable if you go over the lecture slides and homework. No proofs, though there are occasionally slightly sneaky questions. Just know your conversion algorithms (e.g. regular expression to epsilon NFA) and their runtimes, as well as your language closure properties (and constructions for those properties) and you'll be about 90% ready.

The homework is 2-3 hours work each if you do the reading first, and Gradiance is perhaps half an hour. Gradiance allows unlimited retakes, which is pretty neat, though you have to wait 10 minutes between attempts. If you have a lot of time to burn, you can just retake Gradiance often enough to solve all the questions by process of elimination (there's a fairly small pool of answers, so after about 90 minutes you've seen them all).

reviews.content:
I completely disagree with the two reviews below. I had no experience with CS theory before taking this class, but I had a great time and learned SO much, and want to take more theory classes because of this.

Yes, on the first day, and for most of the first two weeks, Choi taught straight from the book, and told us that we could learn from the book just as well as in class. But--and the book is great, don't get me wrong--this proved completely untrue. Over the course of the semester Choi grew a lot as a teacher (it was his first semester teaching!) and gave us his own examples, clear explanations, and answered questions happily. He also seemed to realize that telling students to leave was NOT a good idea, and encouraged us to send him emails and raise our hands in class. The material itself is often hard to grasp, but that's not his fault, and he usually found multiple ways of communicating complicated ideas.

I thought his tests were fine. The final was hard, but was curved, and the midterms were very similar to the homeworks. They were totally doable. 

tldr; Take this class with Choi! He's a really good guy, just a little rough around the edges, who is really willing to help you out and learn from his mistakes.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Standard. Five problem sets, lowest one dropped, which took about four hours of real thinking. Two average midterms, hard final.

reviews.content:
Professor Choi, isn't a good teacher. He often looked just as confused in lectures looking back at us, as we (or at least I) certainly did looking at him. The material itself is very dense, extremely theoretical, and requires some familiarity with proofs based mathematics. Basically, no amount of coding skills will help you in this class, as it is essentially an advanced math class.

The homeworks and midterms are challenging, often requiring insights that are all the more difficult to achieve because Choi's "explanations" often you more confused than before the lecture. Be prepared to spend hours staring at a problem trying simply to decipher the meaning of the question. It is absolutely maddening, and yet, there's no better feeling than figuring out one of those tricky questions. The midterms have many true/false with justification questions with no partial credit, which Choi posts on his exams as T/F/J. I wish I had gone for the pure Justify, without ever definitely answering true or false - I would have done better, as the questions seemed to deliberately be exploiting flaws in common intuition and expectations. 

All in all, this class was a slow, torturous slog through material that had the potential to be interesting, though I don't know if I would go so far as to compare it to the horrors faced by the unfortunate pineapple in the review below. Choi is an uninspired, robotic lecturer who always feels most comfortable reading from the book. There is no reason for anyone to be surprised at this, though, the man basically said as much when he himself advised us to skip lecture on the first day. However, to his credit, he did start to be more responsive to the class's questions and more active in giving us study materials after the entire class performed dismally on a final that he apparently expected to be easy. I think he became more comfortable lecturing as the semester went on, and while I don't think anyone would ever use words like "interesting" to describe those last weeks, they were at least tolerable. He gave a generous curve at end, and so, I think Professor Choi deserves at least a B for effort.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
5 homeworks that are tough worth 20%
2 midterms both tricky  20% each
final wasn't as bad as the midterms, but long

reviews.content: I've had probably some of the worst professors at Columbia including (according to CULPA) "soul sucking professors" and "don't-take-this-class-unless-you're-an-econ-major professors," but I have never had a "I-want-to-kill-myself" kind of professor until I met Seung Geol Choi. On the first day of class, I came in to the lecture room ready and excited to learn about computer science theory. By the end of that hour and a half, I had already begun to dread my upcoming semester. I even wondered if I should have dropped the class that day, but I didn't and now I really wish that I had dropped it and waited for Professor Aho. To describe my experience in Choi's class would be analogous to describing how a pineapple would feel being slowly twisted into my anus. Choi discouraged us from coming to class under any circumstances on the first day of class. I thought he was joking, so I went to the next two lectures. Considering how awful they were (he paraphrased from the textbook in a very incomprehensible manner), I really should have followed his advice in not going to class. The problem sets were painful. I heard he was mean to his TAs. The midterms were pretty bad, but not as catastrophic as the final exam (which was worth 40% of my grade). I did pretty well in all of my midterms and homeworks, and managed to almost fail the class because of the final exam. I sat through the three hours of the final exam wondering when the pain would end and whether I should just kill myself on the spot because it would be better than finishing the exam. Don't take this class under any circumstances. Please. Save yourself.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
- 5 problem sets (spend many hours on these and expect many typos that will be fixed in the last minute)
- 2 midterms (you might think that you did well on these, but don't be fooled! You probably got them all wrong...)
- 1 final (just YOLO that shit)

reviews.content: Without a doubt one of the worst instructors I have ever had the misfortune of encountering here at Columbia University. Unhelpful and inflexible in terms of grading, which was itself extremely harsh. Exams covered a great deal of material that was never taught/explained in lecture, and were extremely esoteric/pedantic in nature, requiring extreme depth of knowledge in these areas. Instructor read straight from textbook, except in a way that was more incomprehensible than the textbook itself (due to his limited English-speaking/comprehension ability), rendering lectures utterly without merit. Choi actively discouraged students from attending lectures or approaching him with questions. 11/10 would not take again; wait for Aho to teach the course,

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
- Biweekly problem sets (20%) (5 per semester) requiring 4-6 hours each.
- 2 difficult midterm exams (20% each) (average = 40 - 70). Little to no partial credit, generous extra credit problem on each is definitely worth doing.
- 1 Final exam (40%)

reviews.content:
I am currently taking Comp Sci Theory with Choi, and I would definitely recommend him.  At first the class was boring, because he taught straight out of the book. By the first midterm, I only came half the time, because it wasn't interesting. Before the midterm, he did an informal survey evaluation to see what the class thought. I was in his office hours before the midterm (like most professors, his office hours are useful if you have specific questions). As we were packing up to leave, he said that the evaluations had been really bad, and he had to figure out how to change the class.
At this point, you might be wondering why on earth you would take this class. Here's the thing: he really listened to the evaluations! I came back to the first class after the midterm, and he had totally changed the way he taught. Instead of going through every proof step-by-step straight out of the book, he focused on the main concepts of the proof. He engaged in a dialogue with the class, asking how we would approach a certain question, and breaking it into manageable chunks. For example, he might start by asking what approach we should take (proof by contradiction, diagonal method, etc). It's amazing what a change there's been in the class.

As far as I'm concerned, if you want a completely formal, rigorous proof of every theorem, you can read the book. (I should mention that the book he uses is very good-- thorough, readable, with useful diagrams.) What Choi's been teaching us is far more valuable-- how to think about a proof, how to go about setting it up. In other words, his class is great for building your logical intuition. 

It's also a fun class, and he makes it seem much more intimate and interactive than you would expect for a hundred-person class (as you would expect, about sixty people show up on any given day). There are twenty or so people who regularly ask questions, and he's learned all their names. It's a comfortable, yet productive atmosphere.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
Very reasonable, especially for a comp sci class: 5 problem sets worth 20%, two midterms worth 20% each, and a final worth 40%. I took Discrete Math with Gross, and the workload is similar. (Unless you've taken a lot of formal, proof-based math classes, you should take Discrete before this class. Plus, Gross is amazing!)

The problem sets are spaced about two weeks apart, except for midterm weeks. They usually took my study partner and me 4-8 hours. If you really understand the concepts, the problem sets are straightforward. If you don't understand the concepts fully, expect them to take longer.

One last note: it's totally okay to get a used version of the textbook. He posts the entire question, so you don't have to worry about the numbers not matching up.

reviews.content:
Aho was possibly the best CS professor I've had at Columbia... and I've had some pretty good other professors before. 

The book (HMU, Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation) is a bit dense. Luckily, his class notes (posted on his website) are a very condensed, very readable summary. They don't cover everything, though, so you'll have to fill the rest in yourself.

Aho is a very clear and straightforward lecturer. No matter what question you ask, he's able to answer it without hardly having to stop to think - almost robotic (in a good way). Few mistakes, doesn't skip a beat. And a good sense of humor to boot.

The midterm and final were straightforward - the problems were difficult, but short (either you knew the answer and could justify it, or you couldn't). No need to memorize tons of proof details when studying, as long as you understood the process and the underlying concepts. Be warned, though, there was at least one trick(y) question on each exam, so you really need to know the material well!

I'm glad I took this class, as it gave me an appreciation for theoretical computer science (particularly lambda calculus) that I never had. It wasn't the most back-breaking CS class I've taken, but it's definitely one that you'll want to dedicate some time to, partly because the material is dense and abstract, and partly because Aho is just an all-around awesome dude.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Four homework assignments. Moderately difficult, though very doable if you start early, work carefully, and ask TAs for help if you need it. Midterm and final were both fair, but there were a few tricky questions on each. Grading seemed fair - a bit on the generous side, but hard to tell.

reviews.content:
Aho is a really really nice Professor. The problem is that he is too smart for his own good. Sometimes it's difficult to understand what he's trying to convey in class until you get to the problem sets and have to work through them. For the most part he tested exactly what he had taught and was very fair about it.

The real difficulty in this class is getting the material. Some people just understand it. Some don't. It's very much like Discrete Math where you are waiting for that ah-ha moment to arrive and suddenly connect the dots and for everything to make sense. Sadly that never came for me.

His stories are pretty funny and they make you realize how cool the CS dept is for having someone like Aho on staff. This is really a hit-or-miss class but I would say take it with Aho if you can.

In retrospect here's how I would have studied for this class if I could go back:
Review your notes after every lecture and then make new notes. Try and see the differences between the various terms (ie: deterministic and non-deterministic, Recursive vs RE). Make sure you understand the theory stuff. Read the book BEFORE the lecture so you have a basic idea of what you're about to do. Do every homework over again before the exams.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
5 problems sets. 1 was really hard and the rest were decent (or at least on-par with what you expect from a CS class).
The midterm was fair. The final had some tricky theory questions which I'm sure tripped people up.

reviews.content:
I looked forward to this class every day---it's probably one of the best courses I've ever taken. Aho is certainly not for everyone: he's a little dry and very odd, but he clearly cares deeply about the material, and does a good job explaining it. 

He's a minor god in  computer science---his portrait is on the wall at the Google offices downtown---and this class is worth taking for that reason if no other; he's also shameless about reminding you of his associations with major gods of computer science, in particular his friend Don (Knuth, that is). If, like me, you enjoyed Gross's digressions, you'll probably also enjoy accounts of evenings spent (no joke) playing violin concertos with the author of "The Art of Computer Programming."

You, like Aho, should care deeply about the material. This is a class about the fundamental questions of computer science---how problems can be described, how they relate to each other, how they are solved, and at the most basic level, what it means to compute. If all you want to do is write Java programs to fit a spec, you shouldn't have bothered with college: the whole point of studying computer science at an institution like this one is to learn how to answer questions like the ones Aho asks, and, you know, do something interesting with your life.

In summary, I had a blast; if you like oddball teachers and hard problems you will too.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Minimal. Five problem sets, four of which took a few hours and one of which caused me to spend an entire weekend staring at a blank sheet of paper (technically an empty LaTeX document, but who's counting?). Easy midterm, easy final.

reviews.content:
Overall: A really great class.

Let's start with the bad: the lectures were not 100% terrific... so I tended to skip lecture sometimes and when I attended I sometimes didn't pay much attention. It's not that he isn't brilliant (he is... for heaven sake's he is the "a" is "awk"), it's just that he has trouble teaching to a class.

Now for the good: His office hours are golden. I cannot stress this enough. If you go into his office hours not understanding something, you'll come out of it completely and utterly understanding the subject; end of story. He is TERRIFIC 1 on 1. The homeworks are incredibly hard, so I recommend checking in during his office hours to double-check your work (or ask for pointers -- no puns intended) before submitting.

The other: As I said, his homeworks are incredibly hard (think Discrete math, but far, far more difficult). One of the last problems he gave us included a proof that HE had made in 1993 or some such proving that the way that perl handled regular expression recognition was NP-complete (when he first proposed this... no one believed him until he proved it). There was no way I could have solved this problem without going to office hours. But moreover, with the possible exception of the aforementioned problem, his assignments, while hard, are pretty fun. I don't mean you'll think they are entertaining, but they are well structured, so they are informative, and if you end up understanding the problem, it really helps you get a comprehensive understanding of the material (which is great). He also gives out practice exams that are incredibly useful. Grading is decently quick and fair.

This class is required for CS majors, so you have to take it, but if you have an option of taking it with or without Aho, take it with.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 1 midterm, 1 final, 6 homework assignments (approx 4-10 hours of work each).

reviews.content:
Potentially a very dry topic, but Prof. Malkin was able to make it interesting. Mostly because she seems to believe a great deal in class participation, and engaged students in every derivation.

Overall, I'd rate her highly.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: ~1 hw per week. 1 midterm, 1 final. Not too bad.

reviews.content:
Hell if I know. I never went.

The website says "CS Theory is the last course required of all CS undergrads", but it should probably be more like "CS theory is the last course of the day, don't bother." The topics mostly overlap with other courses (data structures) -- if you stay at home and read up on regexps and such, you'll be completely fine. The homeworks are basically perfect reflections of what you're accountable for, so if you can do them you're set.

I'm not really complaining about Tal, she's pretty OK. At the end of the day, it's just another CS course repeating the same damn curriculum.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Ten homeworks (good for maybe an hour of work each, if you do the reading). Midterm and final with cheat sheets. Overall, pretty light.

reviews.content:
Prof Malkin is very approachable and is definitely on your side - but she won't go find you, you have to send her e-mails and especially go to her office hours. Her lectures are thorough and cover the book material pretty strictly, but I think she'd be more helpful if she spent a little more time structuring the material, saying "You are here" in the grand scheme of Computation and it's Proofs. Indeed, I think a map could be drawn of the proofs and their relationship to one another - this would help a lot in understanding the dependencies of proofs upon each other.

Whatever you do READ AHEAD OF THE LECTURE. This stuff is nearly impossible to simply hear and absorb in clas, so having thought about the concepts beforehand will make all the difference in the world. Hell, you might even enjoy it.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Not too bad - homeworks don't count for much - but the tests are really based on the homeworks, so if you skip those, you'll be screwed come mid-terms/finals.

reviews.content: The course is interesting, and Prof Feldman really enjoys the material espcially cnsidering that his advisor at MIT was the man who wrote the book you use. He is not the most exciting of lecturers, but he does cover the material in a effecient and clean manor. Prof Feldman is always ready to help, and seems to enjoy students coming to office hours to talk about P vs NP or the Red Sox, its your choice. He is a solid proffesor and I would recommend him if you are going to take computability.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 6 problem sets, worth a lot. 3 quizes worth less. And a Final not worth as much as the problem sets. Get good grades of the p sets and you will be solid.

reviews.content:
The subject is hard, but Zeph is very passionate about it and works hard for his lectures. He must spend a lot of time preparing for his lectures, his homeworks, and exams, therefore, it is expectected that you will also do your part and work hard to meet his expectations. 

the homeworks are VERY time consuming!! and you might not be able to solve all of them yourself, some problems could be easy once in a while, but others could require you to be a genious to come up with a unique efficient solution. It is recommended that you form study groups to do the hws and study for exams, it will make the experience less painful. 

If you master the hws, and the readings of the book and think you are ready for the test, you'll be presented with new problems not seen before that will test how much you internalized the knowledge of  the subject . 

be expected to do a lot of studying on your own, of course that if you are a math person, who loves math and cs theory, you'll be find, but if not, then a lot of work from your part will be needed. 

I enjoyed the class, is one of those classes that when you finish, you take a lot whole information of the subject with you.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
workload: this is very time consuming class!! problem sets everyother week, but they take a lot of time, so start early. 
grading: for the hws, it will depend on your TAs,  many score low on exams and hws, the great think is that there is a big curve, which is  great.

reviews.content:
First let me say: this is a DIFFICULT class. In fact, this is the most difficult non-programming class in all undergraduate computer science classes.

Second, Prof. Grunschlag tries hard to explain the material as best as he can, but sometimes gets carried away in long proofs that won't ever be tested. 

Third, The homework problem sets are very very time consuming and usually you cannot solve all of them by yourself.  Group discussions on the homeworks are strongly encouraged.

Fourth, the tests are slightly easier than the homework problems, but not a lot. The tests do not usually involve lengthy proofs like the homework does, but there are a lot of tricks in the tests that you need to be careful with. 

All in all, a difficult class, but with a VERY BIG curve. So even if you feel you are doing poorly, you are probably OK.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: A problem set every TWO weeks. 2 midterms 1 final. An easy B+ at least.

reviews.content: Great Professor.  Really enjoys the material, and enjoys teaching it.  He'll even bring some humor into the class.  Also, the subject material is really interesting (turing machines, P vs NP, etc).  Also, if you are CS, you have to take the class anyway, and he is pretty much the one that teaches it.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: A few midterms / quizzes and a final, all fair.  A few homeworks, challenging, but not ridiculous.  A fair grader.

reviews.content: Great professor, really seems to like every bit of the class. So, even if you hate the class in the beginning,  his enthusiasm might transmit to you as well.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 5 hwks. midterm, quizz, final, and participation (which actually amounts to 'attendance')

reviews.content: Zeph is a great guy, and he is really interested in you learning, and if he sees you putting in effort into the class he will help you and give you incentive along the way. He is always giving extra credit and stuff. The problem is that this class is hard, and takes a sh**load of time. don't slack off in the begining because those few points you missed on in the begining will come back to haunt you in the end.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 5 problem sets one every other week 6 -8 problems very time consuming. 1 inclass midterm, 1 quiz worth 10% and an inclass final. If you are falling behind do not hesitate to talk to him, and ask for extra credit probs.

reviews.content:
Prof. Malkin is one of the is the best professors I have had in the CS department.  She's brilliant, but can explain topics clearly and doesn't make you feel like a moron.

Go to class because the homework and test questions are based on her lectures.  She's very friendly and approachable.  However, don't even try to BS her.  She will not give out last minute extensions (unless you have an emergency) and collects homework at the beginning of class or it's considered late.

Take the time and do the problem sets yourself.  This is one of those classes where you cannot cram the night before the test and expect to do well.  You have to really understand the concepts.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Problem set every week, reasonable midterm and final.

reviews.content: Great professor who really, really knows her stuff. Lectures well and does not use slides (as Grunschlag does) so going to class is important. Friendly and helpful during office hours. Funny and very likable! Subject material itself is very interesting and creative, but can also confuse and/or frustrate (especially people who are not very mathematical) because it is all proofs and the problems are extremely interrelated and similar. Reading ahead a bit before lecture would definitely help tremendously.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: About 10 problem sets, midterm, final. Quite manageable.

reviews.content: He's a very nice guy and he really wants to help you, but there's a good chance that by the time you go to him for help it'll be too late. The first half of the semester was extremely easy, which is why the second half hits so hard. Before you know it you'll be weeks behind, and at that point falling asleep in class to his not-so-stimulating lectures sounds like a good idea. The best advice is AS SOON as you don't understand ONE THING, no matter how small, get help with it, or you'll be lost for good. He tries so hard to make the students learn so that if you aren't, you'll feel guilty.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Weekly problem sets, increasing in difficulty throughout the semester, midterm, and final.

reviews.content: An immovable boulder in the CS major track, CS students usually put this one off as long as possible. While any class in Computability would be rough, Zeph means well and makes a good-faith effort in this huge and unfriendly subject. His lectures are actually decent and clear (the official word is that he has "gotten alot better" since starting a few years ago), but the class is still best-handled by drinking your new "Computability" brain cells to death the minute the final is over, and not stopping until they're good and dead.  Seriously, though, the organization and clarity of the course overall are better than they might be.  With Zeph, the book is good and you know more or less what is going to be on the tests ahead of time.  Students don't look at an the midterm and go "what the fuck, how can he be asking about THAT random thing!?" as they do in so many other classes.  A hard, hard class, but with that said it's about the best it could be.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Weekly problem sets (this is rough, but it's the only way to get all the material in without it being overwhelming come finals), 2 Midterms (!), Final.

reviews.content: I took Fundamentals of Computer Systems with Professor Kim back in Fall 2022 (before she had the PhD lecturer for the course thankfully – hadn’t been hearing many good things about her). I had a fairly solid experience with the course. I liked learning about the content of the course and in terms of difficulty of grasping the concepts, I thought it was a reasonable progression (although I found MIPS assembly pretty tricky at the time). Prof. Kim seemed fairly approachable (though I haven’t been to her office hours), and she was a decently engaging lecturer. She explained the concepts and went over examples that fell in line with the exam and homework questions. I had the expectations of learning the fundamentals of computer systems, and I would say those expectations were met – binary information representation, boolean algebra, combinational circuit design, sequential circuit design, finite state machines, memory and addressing, MIPS, processors, and caches. All in all, I would recommend taking this course with Kim – I’ve heard mixed reviews about some of the alternatives…
reviews.workload: Fundies with Prof. Kim had two tests (25% each), a MIPS programming assignment (25%), weekly reflections (12.5%), and problem sets (12.5%). The second test focused on content from the second half of the semester. The weekly reflections involved briefly summarizing key points and insights related to the past week’s content and asking lingering questions. The problem sets were each around 5-7 free-response questions related to the course content and at the time, were graded by completion rather than accuracy to encourage using it as study material while being less punitive (which I really appreciated). The only exceptions were the two MIPS programming homework we also had (separate from the programming assignment). The MIPS assignment at the time was to implement binary tree depth-first traversal – admittedly, I wasn’t great at MIPS at the time and didn’t finish. The exams (one mid-semester and the other on the last class meeting of the semester) felt fairly representative of the course content for the two halves of the class, and the difficulty felt relatively fair, so long as you studied sufficiently (I didn’t). For each of these, I would heavily recommend reviewing the homework questions and possibly finding questions similar to them, as the exams’ questions felt similar to these. Also check over potentially making minor mistakes when taking the actual test, as that was one of the pitfalls I fell into when I took the course back then. For the course’s weighting, it felt relatively balanced considering the content of the work that counted for each portion, though I will say I would have liked it if the programming assignment had less weight. On average, I’d say I spent 10-15 hours per week on the class, leaning towards the heavier end when we were in the MIPS unit.

reviews.content: There was quite a bit of repetitive content for each class. A decent amount of time during lectures were also taken by answering students' questions that were usually also repetitive. His slides are really pretty though! He's a really nice person. Though the first midterm was very hard, there was a make up. The two midterms after were fair game. Overall not a bad prof.
reviews.workload: 6 bi-weekly psets graded on completion; 2 in-class midterms (one being a non-cumulative final) and 1 take-home coding assessment.

reviews.content: The content was very repetitive and honestly he's not the greatest lecturer. He's a really nice guy, and the material clicks logically. However, that doesn't translate into being a good class. Every lecture seemed to repeat itself, rather than going into examples that would make sense and help students succeed on the homework. The powerpoints were good diagrams and visual aids, but lacked substance and equations were difficult to find. VERY opaque about grading schemes and had a strange midterm 1 makeup, even though grades for midterm 1 were already curved. This caused a dual-curve system that led to extremely inflated grades, and thus, bad outcomes for students who put work into the course. A 93/100 in the course corresponded to an A-. Extremely unfair curve system.
reviews.workload: 6 problem sets, graded on completion and causing grade inflation. Two midterms, both difficult and longer than the time that we have for the exam itself. One take home midterm for coding. Regrade requests are always ignored.

reviews.content: Brian is great. He’s an incredibly nice professor and is really passionate about systems and robotics. He’s also a great professor who teaches well and deeply cares about students’ feed back. This was his first semester teaching the class so there were some hiccups regarding the first midterm (it was way too long) as noted by a previous review. He made up for this. Our second midterm (take-home for assembly) was a reasonable amount of work and fun, especially discovering the bonus. The third midterm (ie. The final) was very reasonable too even though it was probably the hardest material. Finally, on the last day of class we had the chance to retake the first midterm which was a looot more reasonable. That is, if he’s teaching a future class, don’t worry about what you might have heard about the first midterm.
reviews.workload:
6 psets, not super long or difficult but are good review and preparation for tests. 3 midterms, where the second one is a take home for assembly and the third one is the “final” (standard structure for fundies). We had practice tests from Kim and Rubinstein since this was his first time teaching the class, but the tests were definitely closer in content and difficulty to Kim’s than Rubinstein’s (ie. on the easier side). 

Not sure if Brian is going to be teaching this course more, but if he is, then highly highly recommend!

reviews.content: He's a very nice and approachable teacher, and I found him to be super helpful with everything I asked beyond just this class. Our first midterm was very long and the FSM problem was relatively difficult and so he actually gave the class an option for a redo midterm. Overall the content of this class moves very quickly and towards the end of each lecture becomes very difficult. Overall, he was a good teacher and I found the real issue for me was just the actual curriculum and course content which he has no say over. Otherwise this class was challenging but I enjoyed it a lot and really learned a lot from how he taught it and this emphasis about how Computer Engineering is all about tradeoffs. My best advice for anyone taking this class with him or anyone else is to start studying early and make sure you fully understand concepts in lecture because everything in this class will continue to build on what you learned before.
reviews.workload: We had about 6 problem sets graded on completion that are very useful for exam prep worth 20%, then two in class midterms worth 30% each, and one take home coding exam worth 20%.

reviews.content: Brian is a nice guy. HOWEVER that doe not translate to being a good professor. I just took the midterm and it was more traumatizing than AP. At least with AP you go in expecting to be tricked and do terribly. Brian smiles and fools you into thinking you are prepared. But you are NOT. The exam was the length and difficulty of a pset that takes us 2 weeks to complete.
reviews.workload: psets graded on completion; frustrating because you dont know if your answer (different from answer key bc there are so many possible solutions) would be accepted as correct on an exam or not

reviews.content: I thought this would be decent class going in, but I was wrong. For 85% of the lectures of the fall 2024 semester, Professor Kim's PhD student gave us lectures. She refused to record lectures yet did a poor job at explaining and teaching concepts that aren't actually that complicated. I appreciated that the problems sets and weekly reflections were graded on completion, but this also means it required a lot of self discipline and pacing to make sure that I wasn't doomed when the exams rolled around. I ended up not going to lectures and teaching myself all the material. This was the worst teaching experience I've had at Columbia. And the lack of empathy towards students and their feedback was the cherry on top.
reviews.workload: On average, spent about 10 hours a week outside of class learning lecture material, doing problem sets and reflections, and studying.

reviews.content: I really enjoyed Prof. Barker's lectures! I know some people found her lecture pace to be too fast but I found her lectures very easy to absorb. She was always incredibly prepared and organized for lecture, and answered every single person's questions very comprehensively throughout the entire semester.
reviews.workload: 6 problem sets graded on completion, 2 non-cumulative exams, 1 take-home programming exam (very easy)

reviews.content:
I think a lot of these reviews are rooted in misogyny, which is ESPECIALLY prevalent among CS students. Calling Martha "unqualified" is a lot coming from UNDERGRADUATE students who are nowhere near having their doctorate in CS. Moreover, Fundies is an INTRO course which a PhD candidate is more than qualified to teach. Also, Martha Kim is more than qualified to decide who teaches her course!

I think Martha Barker creates a supportive learning environment which I have rarely experienced as a woman in CS. Many of the professors in the core classes create a hostile environment that ultimately discourage students from asking for help when they are confused. Martha is very receptive and equitable of student's needs. I am someone who has struggled with CS and this has been the best class yet (first class I have done better than the median/mean LOL) because of the supportive environment and clear, slow lectures. She does not tolerate when a student speaks over someone else or is rude in general, which is also a huge problem in the CS department. She does not tolerate students interrupting each other/her or generally being rude to students or her. She definitely is nervous, but I think that does not affect the clarity of her instruction and that people are just mad that a young woman is teaching this course. She does not post recordings publicly, but if you ask her before the lecture that day, she will send it to you. It is a personal choice to not show up to lecture and deal with the consequences of that. Her slides are clear and effective but confusing if you do not come to lecture. Might I add that this is a notoriously difficult course regardless of the professor and most of the reviews seem to ignore that. She does anonymous in-class polls to check in with students for their understanding of the content which is also helpful for knowing where you stand in the course content.

At the end of the day, if you show up to lecture, go to her office hours to ask questions when you are confused, or just to listen, and put in a solid effort before exams, you are almost guaranteed to do well in this course.
reviews.workload:
25% homework - reflections about what was spoken about in lecture and problem sets GRADED ON COMPLETION!!
25% midterm - in-person
25% take home programming midterm
25% non cumulative in-person final

reviews.content: Martha Kim is super kind and understanding, and genuinely cares about how well her students do. She truly does not want to fail anyone and provides generally fair exams. She is a very clear and slow lecturer which is lovely and new in CS. She creates a supportive and understanding environment and wants students to ask questions and clear up their confusion. She gives generous partial credit on exams. I don't really have any complaints. She is one of the nicest and best professors I've had.
reviews.workload:
The class is curved.
25% homework - problem sets graded on completion and written reflections about what we learned in lecture that week
25% in person midterm
25% take home programming exam
25% non-cumulative in person exam

reviews.content: She needs to let Martha Kim teach and just step away and maybe practice teaching a recitation or something.  She refuses to share the recordings of lectures for the purpose of avoiding an empty classroom, but her teaching makes the class so useless, that nobody shows up regardless.  This has been the worst experience in my academic career.
reviews.workload: TA's are so strict on reflections you'd think it was a humanities course and not a literal cs class.

reviews.content: Wow, this has been my worst academic experience at Columbia.
reviews.workload: see other reviews

reviews.content: All the things about her lectures being hard to understand are true. The worst part is that it is hard to ask for help in her class, both her and her TAs treat you very disrespectfully, literally never had this happen in any other class.
reviews.workload: Please refer to the first reviewer's review.

reviews.content: This class is slowly destroying my sanity and mental health.
reviews.workload: It's a lot of work and not much to go on.

reviews.content: It's a bad situation, so not only is extremely hard to understand her lectures, but she also decided to implement a policy where lessons are not recorded. We don't even have the option to try to clarify anything she's said. I don't know why the CS department would do this for such a critical class.
reviews.workload: Everything is bad

reviews.content: Guys I literally can’t do this anymore.
reviews.workload: midterm (25%), take home programming test (25%), second test (25%), problem sets (12.5%), "reflections" (12.5%)

reviews.content: Bro. Like I cannot with her.
reviews.workload: midterm (25%), take home programming test (25%), second test (25%), problem sets (12.5%), "reflections" (12.5%)

reviews.content: My expectations for going into this class was that Martha Kim would be teaching it. Come to my surprise, it's Martha Barker! I am not paying SO much tuition for a PHD student to teach me a core CS class. Barker simply sucks at teaching. She's clearly nervous and really hesitates when it comes to answering questions, which makes it really hard to take her seriously and pay attention in the course. She rushes through the slides and doesn't write anything out but just highlights everything in such neon colors that makes it even harder to understand her material. The course is already extremely difficult and having a professor that sucks at teaching, makes it extra hard. On top of that, when asking for extra review sessions or help on the ed, the TAs just tell you to come to office hours (even though some people may be busy during them). One time I stayed after to ask her a question, and she was extremely condescending and unhelpful. Her slides and lectures compared to Martha Kim's is 10x worse. She also refuses to share her recordings even though we all know she's recording them. Although I go to class every week, I can't understand everything right then and there because there's a large amount of information so having the recordings would be extremely helpful. Overall, she SUCKS as a teacher and sometimes I don't even know if she knows what she's teaching.
reviews.workload: weekly psets and reflections. one midterm and one final both worth 25% each. programming assignment 25%

reviews.content: imagine being in a class that introduces 10 new topics in one go, but you're not able to rewatch the lecture later at all. imagine whispering, asking a question to the person next to you because you're so lost n then be told by the prof to be quiet in front of a like 200 person class. this is what you will get when you sign up for a class with martha barker! i don't understand how you can make this class so fast paced with very minimal slides and *not* allow students to rewatch the lecture later. it's just clearly asking for them to fail? not everyone has the time to go to OH or has the balls to go in there and say "i didn't understand anything from this lecture pls just reteach it to me you underpaid TA!" like c'mon. it's not even halfway through the semester yet and this is my honest review thank u
reviews.workload: Midterm Test (25% of final grade), Take Home Programming Test (25% of final grade), Second Test/Final basically (25% of final grade), Reflections (12.5% of grade), Problem sets (12.5% of grade)

reviews.content:
I really wanted to give Professor Barker the benefit of the doubt. I understand Professor Barker is a PhD student, and she is clearly new to teaching. 

I would also like to share that in her defense, I do not go to office hours simply because I either work at my part-time job or have classes during those times. Additionally, I do not engage on EdStem as much as I should, so I acknowledge that this may be contributing to my generally negative review. Lastly, please do not conflate her person with her teaching. I am sure she is a great person, but I am not a fan of her teaching at all.

I have had my share of terrible professors, but even then, I have never felt as negatively about a professor's teaching before.

Professor Barker simply goes too fast during lectures that they are not even worth attending. After attending every single one of her lectures being fully focused (not looking at my phone and whatnot), I have not been finding any virtue in attending lectures and I find them, in short, a waste of time. I am not exaggerating when I say that after almost four weeks, I have only learned about 15% of the material we have covered in class. Within that 15%, about 80% is material I learned from taking discrete last semester.

Lectures do not help with homework at all. And even if lectures aren't supposed to help with homework, it is ridiculous to expect students to go to office hours to even figure out how to start a homework problem when we pay to take a class to learn things that should help us figure out the homework. Classes should ideally be self-contained.

I am getting to the point where the midterm is a month away, and I am already studying. I study for the entire day. Nonstop. During the weekend. To try to figure out what is going on. The fact that I am already studying and getting so desperate that I printed out and completed maybe 100 pages of midterms from similar courses at other schools to try to get more practice should say a lot. The fact that I am trying very hard, using methods that are tried and true for me in other engineering courses, but still failing to reconcile the gaps within my knowledge should also say a lot.

The textbook is also not very useful, not for the purposes of doing the problem sets at least.

I also do not agree with the policies of this course. I understand that the purpose of making students request to have access to the lecture recordings is to encourage attendance, but more than 50% of people in the class already don't attend lectures. Additionally, one of my friends has gotten a lecture recording before, and they say that having the ability to rewind and slow down the recording makes it so much easier to learn things. Lastly, it is beyond me why lecture recordings expire within seven days. There are many people who use lecture recordings to study for an exam, and the fact that we are denied this avenue to "encourage attendance" is horrendous.

The silver lining? Homeworks are graded on completion at least.
reviews.workload: Please refer to the first reviewer's review.

reviews.content: I decided against taking Fundies with Rubenstein for Martha Kim because my friends told me that Matha is better, BUT she decided to have her grad student Martha Barker teach the course and I am let down a bit. It's clear that she's nervous and because of this, her cadence is really weird, making it difficult to follow along with lecture. I wish she would make recordings available so we can go back and rewatch parts we don't get on the first try. Overall, not impressed and annoyed.
reviews.workload: midterm (25%), take home programming test (25%), second test (25%), problem sets (12.5%), "reflections" (12.5%)

reviews.content: No one went to lecture this semester (I mean like 10-20 people go). Genuinely boring lecturer, difficult to follow along, slide decks are WAY too big (200+ slides). Also, does not seem to care about the students at all. Not only did he not give appropriate accommodations this semester given the protests, but he never even once uttered anything along the lines of 'I hope you all are okay.' Disappointing and disheartening to have professors like him.
reviews.workload: Go to all of your P-credits. It might save you in this class. Homeworks are mid. Exams are difficult, but open book. People either seem to get it in this class or not (I struggled).

reviews.content: Professor Kim is so smart and a great professor! Her lectures are very clear and she is great at explaining things. TA office hours are also super helpful for this class. Exams and psets were very fair and straightforward.
reviews.workload: All homework is for completion which made the class less stressful which was great! But if you actually do all the homework and go to office hours you'll probably end up towards the top of the curve above the people who didn't put effort into the homework. Go to office hours because they are so helpful.

reviews.content:
Death by PowerPoint on a bunch of topics that have no relation to each other and much of which is quite obsolete.
Professor is distant and defensive about her course policies/grading. Would not reconsider requests for partial credit. Promised that coding labs would be retuned before coding take home assignment so we could have some feedback on how coding would be graded. This did not happen.
Tons of mistakes and inconsistencies in PowerPoints.
Worst professor in terms of making material interesting and providing meaningful feedback on graded work I’ve had at Columbia. Try to take this class with a different professor if you can.
reviews.workload:
25% each in class midterm, final
25% take home programming test in MIPS assembly (graded entirely on output, no partial credit for attempts made without output— not told in advance)
12.5% Reflection (each graded out of 2 points— regurgitate the slides into paragraph form on a weekly basis. Massive waste of time.)
12.5% HW (Completion, zero feedback provided even on programming assignments) very long and complicated, super frustrating to get no feedback

reviews.content: Professor Kim was a good lecturer and had great pacing for the course. She always saved time for review sessions prior to exams, and cancelled a fair number of lectures throughout the semester as well which was nice. Her slides alone aren't enough to understand the content, but all of her lectures are recorded, which is a great resource. She was very good at explaining concepts and listening to student feedback as well, so I would definitely recommend her for this course. As for the content itself, I hated it. There were a lot of abstract concepts and conventions that I struggled to grasp and will likely never use again, but I feel like I have a better fundamental understanding of computer hardware now (if I end up remembering anything from this course)
reviews.workload: Psets due every other week that are essentially graded on completion, which was a lifesaver. Weekly reflections that include a summary of in-class learning and any points of confusion are essentially free participation points, as long as you don't forget about them. One midterm, one take-home coding assignment, and one final. The midterm had a low average, but felt like it was a fair difficulty and was doable as long as you understood most concepts at a baseline level. The coding assignment was assigned from Friday to Tuesday before Thanksgiving break and was difficult, but there were no surprises in the grading, i.e. no unseen test cases. Exams weren't cumulative, which was also extremely helpful, since there isn't a direct connection between the first and second half of the content. Overall, I would never take this course if it weren't required, but it wasn't nearly as stressful as AP and it felt like the professor was genuinely trying her best to help make the course doable for everyone.

reviews.content: Good lecturer, tests weren't too difficult.
reviews.workload: Psets graded on completion. Annoying weekly reflections also graded on completion.

reviews.content: Professor Kim is such an incredible professor! I took her course back in Fall 2020 and came back to review because of how much I liked the class. The course teaches an introduction to digital logic and computer hardware fundamentals and she caters the material flawlessly making it digestible whether this is your first time seeing these concepts or not. During the past two years she live streamed the class and saved recordings for students to follow along. Homeworks were a bit time-consuming but covered the material taught in class and gave you great practice for the exams which were very similar questions. I would say she is a very fair instructor and grader, and the material and questions she poses are quite interesting and help you gain more insight into lower-level CS. I strongly recommend her for a fundies instructor.
reviews.workload: The course consisted of weekly reflections, written problem sets, MIPS programming assignment, and midterm + final! The curve was generous.

reviews.content:
Fundies is overall an enjoyable class. Rubenstein does use massive slide decks (typically >100 slides) to teach the material, but aside from the slight difficulty you may encounter when trying to find a specific concept in the slides after the fact, they let him cover a lot of content in detail at a relatively rapid pace. Personally, I liked the speed at which the course was taught. It's also helpful that Rubenstein tends to spend the first 5 minutes of each lecture reviewing what he covered the class before and everything is recorded. Lectures aren't always the most entertaining, but then again there are only so many ways you can make things like MIPS or adders sound exciting. If you've ever wondered fundamentally how a processor works, you'll definitely find it at least somewhat interesting. 

Rubenstein himself is a pretty good lecturer. He sprinkles in some solid (though often underappreciated) jokes every class and is very approachable. He also clearly knows his stuff and can answer pretty much any question thrown at him.
reviews.workload:
Homeworks tend to take a fair bit of thinking, but they're helpful in understanding the material and at the end of the day they're all out of 3 points (you get 2/3 for a solid attempt) and only 10% of the overall grade. The TAs are usually flexible with extensions and the TA office hours (P-credit hours) are really helpful. Except for the MIPS homework, each assignment rarely took more than a few hours. You final grade is also boosted if you go to most of your TA's office hours. 

The midterm and final are moderately difficult and structured identically to the practice exams. For us they were open note, but honestly that didn't help much. Most questions involve designing an appropriate circuit from scratch so the exams take a fair bit of intuition and comfort with implementing basic circuit components (MUXs, decoders, etc). We had 3 hours for both exams and most people stayed for at least the first 2 hours.

reviews.content: Before taking the class, one of my CS friends mentioned how it won't be a headache and that it'll just be annoying. They said if I'm interested in circuits, I'll do fine. Lemme just say... no I'm not doing fine. As a CS major that is not interested in CE or EE, this class is going to be such a headache. The first homework sets will be doable since they deal with binary numbers and K-maps, but after that when you get into MUXs and further, you will struggle a lot on the homeworks. Rubenstein makes the homeworks very challenging, so the only way I'm turning in these PSets is by the help of the TAs explaining and helping me out with them during OH. The midterms and finals are 3 HOURS long and are tough. The curve for the midterm was higher than what I accepted because of the CE majors. Good thing, I didn't take this class seriously or personally and just did the bare minimum. I barely know anything in this class, and I'm cool with that. I'm never gonna use this class as a software engineer in the future. Rubenstein assigns tough problems, but I appreciate his generous grading policy.
